<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Philippines</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Archipelagic country in Southeast Asia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Philippine" redirects here. For the town in the Netherlands, see <a href="/wiki/Philippine,_Netherlands" title="Philippine, Netherlands">Philippine, Netherlands</a>.</div>
<p>
<span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1073938472">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Philippines&amp;params=13_N_122_E_type:country_region:PH"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">13°N</span> <span class="longitude">122°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">13°N 122°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">13; 122</span></span></span></a></span></span></span>
</p>

title="Human Development Index">HDI</a> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(2021)</span></th><td class="infobox-data"><img alt="Decrease" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" title="Decrease" width="11"/> 0.699<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-HDI-13">[11]</a></sup><br/><span class="nowrap"><span style="color:orange">medium</span></span> · <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">116th</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Currency</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Philippine_peso" title="Philippine peso">Philippine peso</a> (<a href="/wiki/Philippine_peso_sign" title="Philippine peso sign">₱</a>) (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">PHP</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Time zone</th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+08:00</span> (<a href="/wiki/Philippine_Standard_Time" title="Philippine Standard Time">PST</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Date format</th><td class="infobox-data"><abbr title="month">mm</abbr>/<abbr title="day">dd</abbr>/<abbr title="year">yyyy</abbr></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Left-_and_right-hand_traffic" title="Left- and right-hand traffic">Driving side</a></th><td class="infobox-data">right<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-c_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-c-16">[c]</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_the_Philippines" title="Telephone numbers in the Philippines">Calling code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_the_Philippines" title="Telephone numbers in the Philippines">+63</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:PH" title="ISO 3166-2:PH">PH</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/.ph" title=".ph">.ph</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <b>Philippines</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'f' in 'find'">f</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="'p' in 'pie'">p</span><span title="/iː/: 'ee' in 'fleece'">iː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'z' in 'zoom'">z</span></span>/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Philippines.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/bf/En-us-Philippines.ogg" title="En-us-Philippines.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>; Filipino: <i lang="fil">Pilipinas</i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[14]</a></sup> officially the <b>Republic of the Philippines</b> (Filipino: <i lang="fil">Republika ng Pilipinas</i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-d_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-d-18">[d]</a></sup> is an <a href="/wiki/Archipelagic_state" title="Archipelagic state">archipelagic country</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>. It is situated in the western Pacific Ocean and consists of around 7,641 islands that are broadly categorized under three main geographical divisions from north to south: <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Visayas" title="Visayas">Visayas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a>. The Philippines is bounded by the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a> to the west, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Sea" title="Philippine Sea">Philippine Sea</a> to the east, and the <a href="/wiki/Celebes_Sea" title="Celebes Sea">Celebes Sea</a> to the southwest. It shares <a href="/wiki/Maritime_boundary" title="Maritime boundary">maritime borders</a> with <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> to the north, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a> to the east and southeast, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> to the south, <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> to the southwest, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> to the west, and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> to the northwest. The Philippines covers an area of 300,000 km<sup>2</sup> (120,000 sq mi) and, as of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, it had a population of around 109 million people,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PH2021_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-PH2021-19">[15]</a></sup> making it the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">thirteenth-most populous country</a>. The Philippines has diverse <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_the_Philippines" title="Ethnic groups in the Philippines">ethnicities</a> and cultures throughout its islands. <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> is the country's capital, while the <a href="/wiki/Cities_of_the_Philippines#Largest_cities" title="Cities of the Philippines">largest city</a> is <a href="/wiki/Quezon_City" title="Quezon City">Quezon City</a>; both lie within the urban area of <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Negrito" title="Negrito">Negritos</a>, some of the archipelago's earliest inhabitants, were followed by <a href="/wiki/Models_of_migration_to_the_Philippines" title="Models of migration to the Philippines">successive waves</a> of <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_peoples" title="Austronesian peoples">Austronesian peoples</a>. Adoption of <a href="/wiki/Animism" title="Animism">animism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> established <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(900%E2%80%931565)" title="History of the Philippines (900–1565)">island-kingdoms</a> called <a href="/wiki/Kedatuan" title="Kedatuan">Kedatuan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Raja" title="Raja">Rajahnates</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Muslim_states_and_dynasties" title="List of Muslim states and dynasties">Sultanates</a>. The arrival of <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan" title="Ferdinand Magellan">Ferdinand Magellan</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> explorer leading a fleet for Spain, marked the beginning of Spanish colonization. In 1543, Spanish explorer <a href="/wiki/Ruy_L%C3%B3pez_de_Villalobos" title="Ruy López de Villalobos">Ruy López de Villalobos</a> named the archipelago <i><span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filipinas" title="es:Filipinas">Las Islas Filipinas</a></i></span></i> in honor of <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain" title="Philip II of Spain">Philip II of Spain</a>. Spanish settlement through <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">Mexico</a>, beginning in 1565, led to the Philippines becoming ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> for more than 300 years. During this time, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholicism" title="Catholicism">Catholicism</a> became the dominant religion, and Manila became the western hub of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_treasure_fleet" title="Spanish treasure fleet">trans-Pacific trade</a>. In 1896, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolution" title="Philippine Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a> began, which then became entwined with the 1898 <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">Spanish–American War</a>. Spain ceded the territory to the United States, while <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_Junta" title="Hong Kong Junta">Filipino revolutionaries</a> declared the <a href="/wiki/First_Philippine_Republic" title="First Philippine Republic">First Philippine Republic</a>. The ensuing <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">Philippine–American War</a> ended with the United States establishing control over the territory, which they maintained until the <a href="/wiki/Philippines_campaign_(1941%E2%80%931942)" title="Philippines campaign (1941–1942)">Japanese invasion</a> of the islands during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. Following <a href="/wiki/Philippines_campaign_(1944%E2%80%931945)" title="Philippines campaign (1944–1945)">liberation</a>, the Philippines became independent in 1946. Since then, the <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign state</a> has often had a tumultuous experience with democracy, which included the overthrow of <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_under_Ferdinand_Marcos" title="Martial law under Ferdinand Marcos">a decades-long dictatorship</a> by <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Revolution" title="People Power Revolution">a nonviolent revolution</a>.
</p><p>The Philippines is an <a href="/wiki/Emerging_market" title="Emerging market">emerging market</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a> whose economy is transitioning from being agriculture centered to services and manufacturing centered. It is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>, <a href="/wiki/ASEAN" title="ASEAN">ASEAN</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">APEC</a> forum, and the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">EAS</a>. The location of the Philippines as an island country on the Pacific <a href="/wiki/Ring_of_Fire" title="Ring of Fire">Ring of Fire</a> that is close to the equator makes it prone to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Earthquakes_in_the_Philippines" title="Earthquakes in the Philippines">earthquakes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Typhoons_in_the_Philippines" title="Typhoons in the Philippines">typhoons</a>. The country has a variety of natural resources and is home to a globally significant <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">level of biodiversity</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Name_of_the_Philippines" title="Name of the Philippines">Name of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Portrait_of_Philip_II_of_Spain_by_Sofonisba_Anguissola_-_002b.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3051" data-file-width="2480" decoding="async" height="209" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Portrait_of_Philip_II_of_Spain_by_Sofonisba_Anguissola_-_002b.jpg/170px-Portrait_of_Philip_II_of_Spain_by_Sofonisba_Anguissola_-_002b.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Portrait_of_Philip_II_of_Spain_by_Sofonisba_Anguissola_-_002b.jpg/255px-Portrait_of_Philip_II_of_Spain_by_Sofonisba_Anguissola_-_002b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Portrait_of_Philip_II_of_Spain_by_Sofonisba_Anguissola_-_002b.jpg/340px-Portrait_of_Philip_II_of_Spain_by_Sofonisba_Anguissola_-_002b.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Portrait_of_Philip_II_of_Spain_by_Sofonisba_Anguissola_-_002b.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain" title="Philip II of Spain">Philip II of Spain</a></div></div></div>
<p>Spanish explorer <a href="/wiki/Ruy_L%C3%B3pez_de_Villalobos" title="Ruy López de Villalobos">Ruy López de Villalobos</a>, during his expedition in 1542, named the islands of <a href="/wiki/Leyte" title="Leyte">Leyte</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samar" title="Samar">Samar</a> "<i><span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Felipinas</i></span></i>" after <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain" title="Philip II of Spain">Philip II of Spain</a>, then the <a href="/wiki/Prince_of_Asturias" title="Prince of Asturias">Prince of Asturias</a>. Eventually the name "<i><span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Las Islas Filipinas</i></span></i>" would be used to cover the archipelago's Spanish possessions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEScott1994[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid15KZU-yMuisCpgPA6_6]_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEScott1994[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid15KZU-yMuisCpgPA6_6]-20">[16]</a></sup> Before Spanish rule was established, other names such as <i><span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Islas del Poniente</i></span></i> (Islands of the West) and Ferdinand Magellan's name for the islands, <i><span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">San Lázaro</i></span></i>, were also used by the Spanish to refer to islands in the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Spate_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-Spate-21">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Friis_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-Friis-22">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Galang_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-Galang-23">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cambridge1_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cambridge1-24">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolution" title="Philippine Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Malolos_Congress" title="Malolos Congress">Malolos Congress</a> proclaimed the establishment of the <i><span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">República Filipina</i></span></i> or the <i><a href="/wiki/First_Philippine_Republic" title="First Philippine Republic">Philippine Republic</a></i>. From the period of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">Spanish–American War</a> (1898) and the <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">Philippine–American War</a> (1899–1902) until the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_the_Philippines" title="Commonwealth of the Philippines">Commonwealth</a> period (1935–1946), American colonial authorities referred to the country as <i>The Philippine Islands</i>, a translation of the Spanish name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constantino1975_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-Constantino1975-25">[21]</a></sup> The United States began the process of changing the reference to the country from <i>The Philippine Islands</i> to <i>The Philippines</i>, specifically when it was mentioned in the Philippine Autonomy Act or the <a href="/wiki/Jones_Law_(Philippines)" title="Jones Law (Philippines)">Jones Law</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[22]</a></sup> The full official title, <i>Republic of the Philippines</i>, was included in the 1935 constitution as the name of the future independent state,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhilIs_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-PhilIs-27">[23]</a></sup> it is also mentioned in all succeeding constitutional revisions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines" title="History of the Philippines">History of the Philippines</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Philippine_history" title="Timeline of Philippine history">Timeline of Philippine history</a>.</div>
<h3><span id="Prehistory_.28pre.E2.80.93900.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_(pre–900)">Prehistory (pre–900)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_the_Philippines" title="Prehistory of the Philippines">Prehistory of the Philippines</a></div>
<p>There is evidence of early <a href="/wiki/Hominini" title="Hominini">hominins</a> living in what is now the Philippines as early as 709,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[26]</a></sup> A small number of bones from <a href="/wiki/Callao_Cave" title="Callao Cave">Callao Cave</a> potentially represent an otherwise unknown species, <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_luzonensis" title="Homo luzonensis">Homo luzonensis</a></i>, that lived around 50,000 to 67,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[28]</a></sup> The oldest <a href="/wiki/Early_modern_human" title="Early modern human">modern human</a> remains found on the islands are from the <a href="/wiki/Tabon_Caves" title="Tabon Caves">Tabon Caves</a> of <a href="/wiki/Palawan" title="Palawan">Palawan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uranium%E2%80%93thorium_dating" title="Uranium–thorium dating">U/Th-dated</a> to 47,000 ± 11–10,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Detroit2004_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-Detroit2004-33">[29]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tabon_Man" title="Tabon Man">Tabon Man</a> is presumably a <a href="/wiki/Negrito" title="Negrito">Negrito</a>, who were among the archipelago's earliest inhabitants, descendants of the first human migrations out of Africa via the coastal route along <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">southern Asia</a> to the now sunken landmasses of <a href="/wiki/Sundaland" title="Sundaland">Sundaland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sahul" title="Sahul">Sahul</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jett2017_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jett2017-34">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first Austronesians reached the Philippines from Taiwan at around 2200 BC, settling the <a href="/wiki/Batanes" title="Batanes">Batanes</a> Islands and northern <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a>. From there, they rapidly spread southwards to the rest of the islands of the Philippines and <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chambers2013_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chambers2013-35">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mijares2006_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-mijares2006-36">[32]</a></sup> This population assimilated with the existing Negritos resulting in the modern <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_the_Philippines" title="Ethnic groups in the Philippines">Filipino ethnic groups</a> which display various ratios of <a href="/wiki/Genetic_admixture" title="Genetic admixture">genetic admixture</a> between Austronesian and Negrito groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lipson2014_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lipson2014-37">[33]</a></sup> Genetic signatures also indicate the possibility of migration of <a href="/wiki/Austroasiatic_languages" title="Austroasiatic languages">Austroasiatic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Papuan_languages" title="Papuan languages">Papuan</a>, and South Asian people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Larena_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-Larena-38">[34]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Philippine_jade_culture" title="Philippine jade culture">Jade artifacts</a> have been found dated to 2000 BC,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEScott198417_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEScott198417-39">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[36]</a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Lingling-o" title="Lingling-o">lingling-o</a> jade items crafted in Luzon made using raw materials originating from Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[37]</a></sup> By 1000 BC, the inhabitants of the archipelago had developed into four kinds of social groups: <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherer</a> tribes, warrior societies, highland <a href="/wiki/Plutocracy" title="Plutocracy">plutocracies</a>, and port principalities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Legarda,_Benito,_Jr._2001_40_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-Legarda,_Benito,_Jr._2001_40-42">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Early_states_.28900.E2.80.931565.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_states_(900–1565)">Early states (900–1565)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(900%E2%80%931565)" title="History of the Philippines (900–1565)">History of the Philippines (900–1565)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1768" data-file-width="2920" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg/220px-Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg/330px-Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg/440px-Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Laguna_Copperplate_Inscription" title="Laguna Copperplate Inscription">Laguna Copperplate Inscription</a>, the oldest known writing found in the Philippines</div></div></div>
<p>The earliest known surviving written record found in the Philippines is the <a href="/wiki/Laguna_Copperplate_Inscription" title="Laguna Copperplate Inscription">Laguna Copperplate Inscription</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Postma1992_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-Postma1992-43">[39]</a></sup> By the 14th century, several the large coastal settlements had emerged as trading centers and became the focal point of societal changes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-44">[40]</a></sup> Some <a href="/wiki/Polity" title="Polity">polities</a> had exchanges with other states across Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-45">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sals2005_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sals2005-46">[42]</a></sup> Trade with China is believed to have begun during the <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a>, and grew more extensive during the <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song dynasty</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[43]</a></sup> and by the second millennium some polities participated in the <a href="/wiki/Tributary_system_of_China" title="Tributary system of China">tributary system of China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEScott1994177–178_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEScott1994177–178-48">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_45-1"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-45">[41]</a></sup> Indian cultural traits, such as linguistic terms and religious practices, began to spread within the Philippines during the 10th century, likely via the Hindu <a href="/wiki/Majapahit" title="Majapahit">Majapahit</a> empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JocanoJr2012_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-JocanoJr2012-49">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_44-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-44">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Osborne2004_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-Osborne2004-50">[46]</a></sup> By the 15th century, Islam was established in the <a href="/wiki/Sulu_Archipelago" title="Sulu Archipelago">Sulu Archipelago</a> and spread from there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McAmis_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-McAmis-51">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>Polities founded in the Philippines from the 10th–16th centuries include <a href="/wiki/Maynila_(historical_polity)" title="Maynila (historical polity)">Maynila</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ring_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ring-52">[48]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tondo_(historical_polity)" title="Tondo (historical polity)">Tondo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Namayan" title="Namayan">Namayan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caboloan" title="Caboloan">Pangasinan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cebu_(historical_state)" title="Cebu (historical state)">Cebu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Butuan_(historical_polity)" title="Butuan (historical polity)">Butuan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Maguindanao" title="Sultanate of Maguindanao">Maguindanao</a>, Lanao, <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Sulu" title="Sultanate of Sulu">Sulu</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ma-i" title="Ma-i">Ma-i</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[49]</a></sup> The early polities were typically made up of three-tier social structures: a nobility class, a class of "freemen", and a class of dependent debtor-bondsmen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_44-2"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-44">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_45-2"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-45">[41]</a></sup> Among the nobility were leaders called "<a href="/wiki/Datu" title="Datu">Datus</a>", responsible for ruling autonomous groups called "<a href="/wiki/Barangay_state" title="Barangay state">barangay</a>" or "dulohan".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_44-3"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-44">[40]</a></sup> When these barangays banded together, either to form a larger settlement<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_44-4"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-44">[40]</a></sup> or a geographically looser alliance,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_45-3"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-45">[41]</a></sup> the more esteemed among them would be recognized as a "paramount datu",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_44-5"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-44">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Legarda,_Benito,_Jr._2001_40_42-1"><a href="#cite_note-Legarda,_Benito,_Jr._2001_40-42">[38]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rajah" title="Rajah">rajah</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Sultan" title="Sultan">sultan</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carley2013_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-Carley2013-54">[50]</a></sup> which headed the community state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[51]</a></sup> Warfare developed and escalated during the 14th to 16th centuries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[52]</a></sup> and throughout these periods population density is thought to have been low,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[53]</a></sup> which was also caused by the <a href="/wiki/Typhoon#Frequency" title="Typhoon">frequency of typhoons</a> and the Philippines' location on the Pacific <a href="/wiki/Ring_of_Fire" title="Ring of Fire">Ring of Fire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[54]</a></sup> In 1521, Portuguese explorer <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan" title="Ferdinand Magellan">Ferdinand Magellan</a> arrived in the area, claimed the islands for Spain and was then killed by <a href="/wiki/Lapulapu" title="Lapulapu">Lapulapu</a>'s fighters at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Mactan" title="Battle of Mactan">Battle of Mactan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etymology_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-etymology-59">[55]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Colonial_rule_.281565.E2.80.931946.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_rule_(1565–1946)">Colonial rule (1565–1946)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1565%E2%80%931898)" title="History of the Philippines (1565–1898)">History of the Philippines (1565–1898)</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1898%E2%80%931946)" title="History of the Philippines (1898–1946)">History of the Philippines (1898–1946)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vista_del_Puente_de_Manila_(1847).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="508" data-file-width="734" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Vista_del_Puente_de_Manila_%281847%29.png/220px-Vista_del_Puente_de_Manila_%281847%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Vista_del_Puente_de_Manila_%281847%29.png/330px-Vista_del_Puente_de_Manila_%281847%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Vista_del_Puente_de_Manila_%281847%29.png/440px-Vista_del_Puente_de_Manila_%281847%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vista_del_Puente_de_Manila_(1847).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Manila in 1847.</div></div></div>
<p>Colonization began when Spanish explorer <a href="/wiki/Miguel_L%C3%B3pez_de_Legazpi" title="Miguel López de Legazpi">Miguel López de Legazpi</a> arrived from Mexico in 1565.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Basques_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-Basques-61">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 20–23">: 20–23 </span></sup> In 1571, <a href="/wiki/Intramuros" title="Intramuros">Spanish Manila</a> became the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">Spanish East Indies</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[58]</a></sup> which encompassed Spanish territories in Asia and the Pacific.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Andrade_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-Andrade-64">[60]</a></sup> The Spanish successfully invaded the different local states by employing the principle of <a href="/wiki/Divide_and_rule" title="Divide and rule">divide and conquer</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[61]</a></sup> bringing most of what is now the Philippines into a single unified administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto5_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-66">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[63]</a></sup> Disparate barangays were deliberately <a href="/wiki/Reductions" title="Reductions">consolidated into towns</a>, where <a href="/wiki/Friars_in_Spanish_Philippines" title="Friars in Spanish Philippines">Catholic missionaries</a> were more easily able to convert the inhabitants to <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abinales_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-Abinales-68">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 53, 68">: 53, 68 </span></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[65]</a></sup> From 1565 to 1821, the Philippines was governed as a territory of the <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>-based <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">Viceroyalty of New Spain</a>, and later administered from <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">Mexican War of Independence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[66]</a></sup> Manila was the western hub of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_treasure_fleet" title="Spanish treasure fleet">trans-Pacific trade</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kane_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kane-71">[67]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Manila_galleon" title="Manila galleon">Manila galleons</a> were constructed in <a href="/wiki/Bicol_Region" title="Bicol Region">Bicol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cavite" title="Cavite">Cavite</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p>During its rule, Spain quelled <a href="/wiki/Philippine_revolts_against_Spain" title="Philippine revolts against Spain">various indigenous revolts</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Halili_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-Halili-74">[70]</a></sup> as well as defending against external military challenges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ooi2004_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ooi2004-75">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[72]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (January 2021)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup> Spanish forces included soldiers from elsewhere in New Spain<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[73]</a></sup> as well as broader <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Asian" title="Latin American Asian">Latin America</a>, many of whom deserted and intermingled with the wider population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UnrulyMexicans_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-UnrulyMexicans-78">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[76]</a></sup> Immigration blurred the racial caste system<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abinales_68-1"><a href="#cite_note-Abinales-68">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 97–98">: 97–98 </span></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-81">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[78]</a></sup> Spain maintained in towns and cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[79]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_La_Naval_de_Manila" title="Battles of La Naval de Manila">War against the Dutch</a> from the west, in the 17th century, together with conflict with the Muslims in the south nearly bankrupted the colonial treasury.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>Administration of the Philippine islands was considered a drain on the economy of Spain,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ooi2004_75-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ooi2004-75">[71]</a></sup> and there were debates to abandon it or trade it for other territory. However, this was opposed because of economic potential, security, and the desire to continue religious conversion in the islands and the surrounding region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[82]</a></sup> The Philippines survived on an annual subsidy provided by the Spanish Crown,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ooi2004_75-2"><a href="#cite_note-Ooi2004-75">[71]</a></sup> which averaged 250,000 pesos<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[83]</a></sup> and was usually paid through the provision of 75 tons of silver bullion being sent from the Americas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[84]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/British_occupation_of_Manila" title="British occupation of Manila">British forces occupied Manila</a> from 1762 to 1764 during the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a>, with Spanish rule restored through the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1763)" title="Treaty of Paris (1763)">1763 Treaty of Paris</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Basques_61-1"><a href="#cite_note-Basques-61">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 81–83">: 81–83 </span></sup> The Spanish considered their war with the Muslims in Southeast Asia an extension of the <a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[85]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93Moro_conflict" title="Spanish–Moro conflict">Spanish–Moro conflict</a> lasted for several hundred years. In the last quarter of the 19th century, Spain conquered portions of <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jolo,_Sulu" title="Jolo, Sulu">Jolo</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[86]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Moro_people" title="Moro people">Moro</a> Muslims in the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Sulu" title="Sultanate of Sulu">Sultanate of Sulu</a> formally recognized Spanish sovereignty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ilustrados_1890.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1029" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ilustrados_1890.jpg/250px-Ilustrados_1890.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ilustrados_1890.jpg/375px-Ilustrados_1890.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ilustrados_1890.jpg/500px-Ilustrados_1890.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ilustrados_1890.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Filipino <i><a href="/wiki/Ilustrado" title="Ilustrado">Ilustrados</a></i> in Spain formed the <a href="/wiki/Propaganda_Movement" title="Propaganda Movement">Propaganda Movement</a>. Photographed in 1890.</div></div></div>
<p>In the 19th century, Philippine ports opened to world trade, and shifts started occurring within Filipino society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[90]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Decolonization_of_the_Americas" title="Decolonization of the Americas">Latin American wars of independence</a> and renewed immigration led to shifts in social identity, with the term <i>Filipino</i> shifting from referring to <a href="/wiki/Criollo_people" title="Criollo people">Spaniards born in the Philippines</a> to a term encompassing all people in the archipelago. This identity shift was driven by wealthy <a href="/wiki/Mestizo" title="Mestizo">families of mixed ancestry</a>, to which it became a national identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[91]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>Revolutionary sentiments were stoked in 1872 after <a href="/wiki/Gomburza" title="Gomburza">three activist Catholic priests</a> were executed on weak pretences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cavite_Mutiny_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cavite_Mutiny-99">[95]</a></sup> This would inspire a <a href="/wiki/Propaganda_Movement" title="Propaganda Movement">propaganda movement</a> in Spain, organized by <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_H._del_Pilar" title="Marcelo H. del Pilar">Marcelo H. del Pilar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Rizal" title="José Rizal">José Rizal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Graciano_L%C3%B3pez_Jaena" title="Graciano López Jaena">Graciano López Jaena</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Ponce" title="Mariano Ponce">Mariano Ponce</a>, lobbying for political reforms in the Philippines. Rizal was executed on December 30, 1896, on charges of rebellion. This radicalized many who had previously been loyal to Spain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA1_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA1-100">[96]</a></sup> As attempts at reform met with resistance, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Bonifacio" title="Andrés Bonifacio">Andrés Bonifacio</a> in 1892 established the militant secret society called the <a href="/wiki/Katipunan" title="Katipunan">Katipunan</a>, who sought independence from Spain through armed revolt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Katipunan <a href="/wiki/Cry_of_Pugad_Lawin" title="Cry of Pugad Lawin">started</a> the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolution" title="Philippine Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a> in 1896.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[98]</a></sup> Internal disputes led to <a href="/wiki/Tejeros_Convention" title="Tejeros Convention">an election</a> in which Bonifacio lost his position and <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Aguinaldo" title="Emilio Aguinaldo">Emilio Aguinaldo</a> was elected as the new leader of the revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Duka_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-Duka-103">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 145–147">: 145–147 </span></sup> In 1897, the <a href="/wiki/Pact_of_Biak-na-Bato" title="Pact of Biak-na-Bato">Pact of Biak-na-Bato</a> brought about the <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_Junta" title="Hong Kong Junta">exile of the revolutionary leadership to Hong Kong</a>. In 1898, the <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">Spanish–American War</a> began and reached the Philippines. Aguinaldo returned, resumed the revolution, and <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Philippine Declaration of Independence">declared independence</a> from Spain on June 12, 1898.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abinales_68-2"><a href="#cite_note-Abinales-68">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 112–113">: 112–113 </span></sup> The <a href="/wiki/First_Philippine_Republic" title="First Philippine Republic">First Philippine Republic</a> was established on January 21, 1899.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1199" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg/220px-Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg/330px-Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg/440px-Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_Douglas_MacArthur" title="General Douglas MacArthur">General Douglas MacArthur</a> coming ashore during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Leyte" title="Battle of Leyte">Battle of Leyte</a> on October 20, 1944</div></div></div>
<p>The islands had been <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1898)" title="Treaty of Paris (1898)">ceded by Spain</a> to the United States along with <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico" title="Puerto Rico">Puerto Rico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">Guam</a> as a result of the latter's victory in the <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">Spanish–American War</a> in 1898.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[101]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[102]</a></sup> As it became increasingly clear the United States would not recognize the First Philippine Republic, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">Philippine–American War</a> broke out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[103]</a></sup> The war resulted in the deaths of 250,000 to 1 million civilians, mostly because of famine and disease.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[104]</a></sup> After the defeat of the First Philippine Republic in 1902, an <a href="/wiki/Insular_Government_of_the_Philippine_Islands" title="Insular Government of the Philippine Islands">American civilian government</a> was established through the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Organic_Act_(1902)" title="Philippine Organic Act (1902)">Philippine Organic Act</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gates_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gates-109">[105]</a></sup> American forces continued to secure and extend their control over the islands, suppressing an attempted <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_Republic#Sakay" title="Tagalog Republic">extension of the Philippine Republic</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Duka_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-Duka-103">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 200–202">: 200–202 </span></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-antonio_abad_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-antonio_abad-110">[106]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kiram%E2%80%93Bates_Treaty" title="Kiram–Bates Treaty">securing the Sultanate of Sulu</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bates_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bates-111">[107]</a></sup> and establishing control over interior mountainous areas that had resisted Spanish conquest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>Cultural developments strengthened the continuing development of a national identity,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.com_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-113">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[110]</a></sup> and Tagalog began to take precedence over other local languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abinales_68-3"><a href="#cite_note-Abinales-68">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 121">: 121 </span></sup> Governmental functions were gradually devolved to Filipinos under the <a href="/wiki/Taft_Commission" title="Taft Commission">Taft Commission</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ooi_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ooi-115">[111]</a></sup> and in 1935 the Philippines <a href="/wiki/Tydings%E2%80%93McDuffie_Act" title="Tydings–McDuffie Act">was granted</a> <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_the_Philippines" title="Commonwealth of the Philippines">Commonwealth</a> status with <a href="/wiki/Manuel_L._Quezon" title="Manuel L. Quezon">Manuel Quezon</a> as president and <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Osme%C3%B1a" title="Sergio Osmeña">Sergio Osmeña</a> as vice president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[112]</a></sup> Quezon's priorities were defence, social justice, inequality and economic diversification, and national character.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ooi_115-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ooi-115">[111]</a></sup> Tagalog was designated the <a href="/wiki/Filipino_language" title="Filipino language">national language</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[113]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/1937_Philippine_women%27s_suffrage_plebiscite" title="1937 Philippine women's suffrage plebiscite">women's suffrage was introduced</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[114]</a></sup> and land reform mooted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Manapat,_Carlos_2010_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-Manapat,_Carlos_2010-120">[116]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_the_Philippines_during_World_War_II" title="Military history of the Philippines during World War II">During World War II</a> the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japanese Empire</a> <a href="/wiki/Philippines_campaign_(1941%E2%80%931942)" title="Philippines campaign (1941–1942)">invaded</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[117]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Second_Philippine_Republic" title="Second Philippine Republic">Second Philippine Republic</a>, under <a href="/wiki/Jose_P._Laurel" title="Jose P. Laurel">Jose P. Laurel</a>, was established as a <a href="/wiki/Puppet_state" title="Puppet state">puppet state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[119]</a></sup> From 1942 the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_the_Philippines" title="Japanese occupation of the Philippines">Japanese occupation of the Philippines</a> was <a href="/wiki/Philippine_resistance_against_Japan" title="Philippine resistance against Japan">opposed</a> by large-scale <a href="/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_the_Philippines#Resistance" title="Japanese occupation of the Philippines">underground guerrilla activity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McAAE_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-McAAE-124">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[122]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes" title="Japanese war crimes">Atrocities and war crimes</a> were committed during the war, including the <a href="/wiki/Bataan_Death_March" title="Bataan Death March">Bataan Death March</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Manila_massacre" title="Manila massacre">Manila massacre</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[124]</a></sup> Allied troops <a href="/wiki/Philippines_campaign_(1944%E2%80%931945)" title="Philippines campaign (1944–1945)">defeated the Japanese</a> in 1945. It is estimated that over one million Filipinos had died by the end of the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rottman_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rottman-129">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[126]</a></sup> On October 11, 1945, the Philippines became one of the <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations" title="Member states of the United Nations">founding members</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[127]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bühler_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bühler-132">[128]</a></sup> On July 4, 1946, the Philippines was officially recognized by the United States as an independent nation through the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Manila_(1946)" title="Treaty of Manila (1946)">Treaty of Manila</a>, during the presidency of <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Roxas" title="Manuel Roxas">Manuel Roxas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bühler_132-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bühler-132">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Treaty_of_Manila_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-Treaty_of_Manila-133">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Independence_.281946.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_(1946–present)">Independence (1946–present)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1946%E2%80%931965)" title="History of the Philippines (1946–1965)">History of the Philippines (1946–1965)</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1965%E2%80%931986)" title="History of the Philippines (1965–1986)">History of the Philippines (1965–1986)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1986%E2%80%93present)" title="History of the Philippines (1986–present)">History of the Philippines (1986–present)</a></div>
<p>Efforts to end the <a href="/wiki/Hukbalahap_Rebellion" title="Hukbalahap Rebellion">Hukbalahap Rebellion</a> began during <a href="/wiki/Elpidio_Quirino" title="Elpidio Quirino">Elpidio Quirino</a>'s term,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[131]</a></sup> however, it was only during <a href="/wiki/Ramon_Magsaysay" title="Ramon Magsaysay">Ramon Magsaysay</a>'s presidency that the movement was suppressed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[132]</a></sup> Magsaysay's successor, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_P._Garcia" title="Carlos P. Garcia">Carlos P. Garcia</a>, initiated the <a href="/wiki/Filipino_First_policy" title="Filipino First policy">Filipino First Policy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[133]</a></sup> which was continued by <a href="/wiki/Diosdado_Macapagal" title="Diosdado Macapagal">Diosdado Macapagal</a>, with celebration of Independence Day moved from July 4 to June 12, the date of Emilio Aguinaldo's declaration,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bibingka-jun12_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-bibingka-jun12-138">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[135]</a></sup> and pursuit of <a href="/wiki/North_Borneo_dispute" title="North Borneo dispute">a claim</a> on the eastern part of <a href="/wiki/North_Borneo" title="North Borneo">North Borneo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1965, Macapagal lost the presidential election to <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Marcos" title="Ferdinand Marcos">Ferdinand Marcos</a>. Early in his presidency, Marcos initiated numerous infrastructure projects<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[138]</a></sup> but, together with his wife <a href="/wiki/Imelda_Marcos" title="Imelda Marcos">Imelda</a>, was accused of corruption and embezzling billions of dollars in public funds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[139]</a></sup> Nearing the end of his term, Marcos declared <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_the_Philippines" title="Martial law in the Philippines">martial law</a> on September 21, 1972.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[141]</a></sup> This period of his rule was characterized by political repression, censorship, and human rights violations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[142]</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 21, 1983, Marcos' chief rival, opposition leader <a href="/wiki/Ninoy_Aquino" title="Ninoy Aquino">Benigno Aquino Jr.</a>, was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Benigno_Aquino_Jr." title="Assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr.">assassinated on the tarmac</a> at <a href="/wiki/Ninoy_Aquino_International_Airport" title="Ninoy Aquino International Airport">Manila International Airport</a>. Marcos called a snap <a href="/wiki/1986_Philippine_presidential_election" title="1986 Philippine presidential election">presidential election in 1986</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandler_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chandler-147">[143]</a></sup> Marcos was proclaimed the winner, but the results were widely regarded as fraudulent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:7_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-:7-148">[144]</a></sup> The resulting protests led to the <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Revolution" title="People Power Revolution">People Power Revolution</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gandhi_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi-149">[145]</a></sup> which forced Marcos and his allies to flee to <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaii</a>, and Aquino's widow, <a href="/wiki/Corazon_Aquino" title="Corazon Aquino">Corazon Aquino</a>, was installed as president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandler_147-1"><a href="#cite_note-Chandler-147">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[146]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1923" data-file-width="2875" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg/220px-Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg/330px-Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg/440px-Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/1991_eruption_of_Mount_Pinatubo" title="1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo">1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo</a> was the second largest volcanic eruption of the 20th century.</div></div></div>
<p>The return of democracy and government reforms beginning in 1986 were hampered by national debt, government corruption, and <a href="/wiki/Coup_attempts_against_Corazon_Aquino" title="Coup attempts against Corazon Aquino">coup attempts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[148]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Communist_rebellion_in_the_Philippines" title="Communist rebellion in the Philippines">communist insurgency</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[150]</a></sup> and a military conflict with <a href="/wiki/Moro_conflict" title="Moro conflict">Moro separatists</a> persisted,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[151]</a></sup> while the administration also faced a series of disasters, including the sinking of the <i><a href="/wiki/MV_Do%C3%B1a_Paz" title="MV Doña Paz">MV Doña Paz</a></i> in December 1987,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt1_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt1-156">[152]</a></sup> and the eruption of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Pinatubo" title="Mount Pinatubo">Mount Pinatubo</a> in June 1991.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[153]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[154]</a></sup> Aquino was succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Fidel_V._Ramos" title="Fidel V. Ramos">Fidel V. Ramos</a>, whose economic performance, at 3.6% growth rate,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lastlaugh_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-lastlaugh-159">[155]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[156]</a></sup> was overshadowed by the onset of the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">1997 Asian financial crisis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AFC-NA-13_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-AFC-NA-13-161">[157]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AFC-NA-14_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-AFC-NA-14-162">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ramos' successor, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Estrada" title="Joseph Estrada">Joseph Estrada</a>, was overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/Second_EDSA_Revolution" title="Second EDSA Revolution">2001 EDSA Revolution</a> and succeeded by his vice president, <a href="/wiki/Gloria_Macapagal_Arroyo" title="Gloria Macapagal Arroyo">Gloria Macapagal Arroyo</a>, on January 20, 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[159]</a></sup> Arroyo's 9-year administration was marked by economic growth<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[160]</a></sup> but was tainted by corruption and political scandals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[161]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[162]</a></sup> On November 23, 2009, 34 journalists and several civilians were <a href="/wiki/Maguindanao_massacre" title="Maguindanao massacre">killed in Maguindanao</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[163]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maptimeline_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-maptimeline-168">[164]</a></sup>
</p><p>Economic growth continued during <a href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino_III" title="Benigno Aquino III">Benigno Aquino III</a>'s administration, which pushed for good governance and transparency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[166]</a></sup> In 2015, a <a href="/wiki/Mamasapano_clash" title="Mamasapano clash">shootout in Mamasapano</a> resulted in the death of 44 members of the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_National_Police" title="Philippine National Police">Philippine National Police</a>-<a href="/wiki/Special_Action_Force" title="Special Action Force">Special Action Force</a>, which caused a delay in the passage of the <a href="/wiki/Bangsamoro_Organic_Law" title="Bangsamoro Organic Law">Bangsamoro Organic Law</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p>Former <a href="/wiki/Davao_City" title="Davao City">Davao City</a> mayor <a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_Duterte" title="Rodrigo Duterte">Rodrigo Duterte</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2016_Philippine_presidential_election" title="2016 Philippine presidential election">2016 presidential election</a>, becoming the first president from Mindanao.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2016_election_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-2016_election-173">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[170]</a></sup> Duterte launched <a href="/wiki/Philippine_drug_war" title="Philippine drug war">an anti-drug campaign</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[172]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Build!_Build!_Build!" title="Build! Build! Build!">an infrastructure program</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[174]</a></sup> The implementation in 2018 of the Bangsamoro Organic Law led to the creation of the autonomous <a href="/wiki/Bangsamoro" title="Bangsamoro">Bangsamoro</a> region in Mindanao.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-willitlast_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-willitlast-179">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CarolynArguillas20190126_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-CarolynArguillas20190126-180">[176]</a></sup> In early 2020, the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_Philippines" title="COVID-19 pandemic in the Philippines">COVID-19 pandemic</a> reached the country<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-181">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-phconfirms_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-phconfirms-182">[178]</a></sup> causing the gross domestic product to shrink by 9.5%, the country's worst annual economic performance since records began in 1947.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>Marcos' son, <a href="/wiki/Bongbong_Marcos" title="Bongbong Marcos">Bongbong Marcos</a>, won the <a href="/wiki/2022_Philippine_presidential_election" title="2022 Philippine presidential election">2022 presidential election</a>, together with Duterte's daughter, <a href="/wiki/Sara_Duterte" title="Sara Duterte">Sara Duterte</a>, as <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_Philippines" title="Vice President of the Philippines">vice president</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[180]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography_and_environment">Geography and environment</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_the_Philippines" title="Geography of the Philippines">Geography of the Philippines</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_the_Philippines" title="List of islands of the Philippines">List of islands of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3120" data-file-width="2134" decoding="async" height="249" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png/170px-Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png/255px-Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png/340px-Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Topography of the Philippines</div></div></div>
<p>The Philippines is an <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> composed of about 7,640 <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_the_Philippines" title="List of islands of the Philippines">islands</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Islands_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-Islands-185">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[182]</a></sup> covering a total area, including inland bodies of water, of around 300,000 square kilometers (115,831 sq mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boquet_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boquet-188">[184]</a></sup> with cadastral survey data suggesting it may be larger.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[185]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone_of_the_Philippines" title="Exclusive economic zone of the Philippines">exclusive economic zone of the Philippines</a> covers 2,263,816 km<sup>2</sup> (874,064 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[186]</a></sup> Its 36,289 kilometers (22,549 mi) coastline gives it the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_length_of_coastline" title="List of countries by length of coastline">fifth-longest coastline</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfields_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfields-191">[187]</a></sup> It is located between 116° 40', and 126° 34' E longitude and 4° 40' and 21° 10' N latitude and is bordered by the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Sea" title="Philippine Sea">Philippine Sea</a> to the east,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[189]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a> to the west,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[190]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Celebes_Sea" title="Celebes Sea">Celebes Sea</a> to the south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[191]</a></sup> The island of <a href="/wiki/Borneo" title="Borneo">Borneo</a> is located a few hundred kilometers southwest,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[192]</a></sup> and Taiwan is located directly to the north. <a href="/wiki/Sulawesi" title="Sulawesi">Sulawesi</a> is located to the southwest, and <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a> is located to the east of the islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[193]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/List_of_mountains_in_the_Philippines" title="List of mountains in the Philippines">highest mountain</a> is <a href="/wiki/Mount_Apo" title="Mount Apo">Mount Apo</a>, measuring up to 2,954 meters (9,692 ft) above sea level and located on the island of <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[195]</a></sup> Running east of the archipelago, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Trench" title="Philippine Trench">Philippine Trench</a> extends 10,540-meter (34,580 ft) down at the <a href="/wiki/Emden_Deep" title="Emden Deep">Emden Deep</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[196]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[198]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_the_Philippines" title="List of rivers of the Philippines">longest river</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Cagayan_River" title="Cagayan River">Cagayan River</a> in northern <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a>, measuring about 520 kilometers (320 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[199]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Manila_Bay" title="Manila Bay">Manila Bay</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jacinto_et_al_(A)_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jacinto_et_al_(A)-204">[200]</a></sup> upon the shore of which the capital city of Manila lies, is connected to <a href="/wiki/Laguna_de_Bay" title="Laguna de Bay">Laguna de Bay</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[201]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_of_the_Philippines" title="List of lakes of the Philippines">largest lake</a> in the Philippines, by the <a href="/wiki/Pasig_River" title="Pasig River">Pasig River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rehabinfo_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-rehabinfo-206">[202]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Princesa_Subterranean_River_National_Park" title="Puerto Princesa Subterranean River National Park">Puerto Princesa Subterranean River</a>, which runs 8.2 kilometers (5.1 mi) underground through a <a href="/wiki/Karst" title="Karst">karst</a> landscape before reaching the ocean, is a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[203]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Mayon_Volcano.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3936" data-file-width="2624" decoding="async" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/The_Mayon_Volcano.jpg/220px-The_Mayon_Volcano.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/The_Mayon_Volcano.jpg/330px-The_Mayon_Volcano.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/The_Mayon_Volcano.jpg/440px-The_Mayon_Volcano.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Mayon_Volcano.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mayon" title="Mayon">Mayon</a> is an active <a href="/wiki/Stratovolcano" title="Stratovolcano">stratovolcano</a>, located in the south of the island of Luzon</div></div></div>
<p>Situated on the western fringes of the Pacific <a href="/wiki/Ring_of_Fire" title="Ring of Fire">Ring of Fire</a>, the Philippines experiences frequent seismic and volcanic activity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[204]</a></sup> The Philippine region is <a href="/wiki/Seismology" title="Seismology">seismically</a> active and has been progressively constructed by <a href="/wiki/Subduction_tectonics_of_the_Philippines" title="Subduction tectonics of the Philippines">plates</a> converging towards each other in multiple directions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarthScience2005_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-EarthScience2005-211">[207]</a></sup> Around five earthquakes are registered daily, though most are too weak to be felt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EarthScience2005_211-1"><a href="#cite_note-EarthScience2005-211">[207]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_the_Philippines" title="List of earthquakes in the Philippines">last major earthquakes</a> were the <a href="/wiki/1976_Moro_Gulf_earthquake" title="1976 Moro Gulf earthquake">1976 Moro Gulf earthquake</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1990_Luzon_earthquake" title="1990 Luzon earthquake">1990 Luzon earthquake</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[209]</a></sup> There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_active_volcanoes_in_the_Philippines" title="List of active volcanoes in the Philippines">many active volcanoes</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Mayon" title="Mayon">Mayon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Pinatubo" title="Mount Pinatubo">Mount Pinatubo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taal_Volcano" title="Taal Volcano">Taal Volcano</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PHIVOLCS-Volcanoes_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-PHIVOLCS-Volcanoes-214">[210]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1991_eruption_of_Mount_Pinatubo" title="1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo">eruption of Mount Pinatubo in June 1991</a> produced the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_volcanic_eruptions_1500_-_1999" title="List of volcanic eruptions 1500 - 1999">second largest terrestrial eruption</a> of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pinatubo1991_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pinatubo1991-215">[211]</a></sup> The Philippines is the world's second-biggest <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_power_in_the_Philippines" title="Geothermal power in the Philippines">geothermal energy producer</a> behind the United States, with 18% of <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_the_Philippines" title="Energy in the Philippines">the country's electricity</a> needs being met by geothermal power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[212]</a></sup>
