</p><p>The country has valuable<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Inquirer-PhilippinesSits_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-Inquirer-PhilippinesSits-217">[213]</a></sup> mineral deposits as a result of its complex geologic structure and high level of seismic activity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[214]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[215]</a></sup> The Philippines is thought to have the second-largest gold deposits after South Africa, along with a large amount of copper deposits,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimesMiners_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimesMiners-220">[216]</a></sup> and the world's largest deposits of <a href="/wiki/Palladium" title="Palladium">palladium</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Inquirer-FirmSeesMetal_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-Inquirer-FirmSeesMetal-221">[217]</a></sup> Other minerals include chromite, nickel, and zinc. Despite this, a lack of law enforcement, poor management, opposition because of the presence of indigenous communities, and past instances of environmental damage and disaster have resulted in these mineral resources remaining largely untapped.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimesMiners_220-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimesMiners-220">[216]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[218]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_the_Philippines" title="Wildlife of the Philippines">Wildlife of the Philippines</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_threatened_species_of_the_Philippines" title="List of threatened species of the Philippines">List of threatened species of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="264" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg/220px-Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg/330px-Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg/440px-Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_Eagle" title="Philippine Eagle">Philippine Eagle</a> is endemic to the forests of the country.</div></div></div>
<p>The Philippines is a <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse country</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chanco_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chanco-223">[219]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AUSGOP_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-AUSGOP-224">[220]</a></sup> Eight major types of forests are distributed throughout the Philippines; <a href="/wiki/Dipterocarpaceae" title="Dipterocarpaceae">dipterocarp</a>, beach forest, <a href="/wiki/Pine" title="Pine">pine</a> forest, <a href="/wiki/Vitex_parviflora" title="Vitex parviflora">molave</a> forest, <a href="/wiki/Montane_ecosystems" title="Montane ecosystems">lower montane forest</a>, upper montane or <a href="/wiki/Cloud_forest" title="Cloud forest">mossy forest</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mangrove" title="Mangrove">mangroves</a>, and ultrabasic forest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[221]</a></sup> As of 2021, the Philippines has 7 million hectares of forest cover, according to official estimates, though experts contend that the actual figure is likely much lower.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[222]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">Deforestation</a>, often the result of <a href="/wiki/Illegal_logging" title="Illegal logging">illegal logging</a>, is <a href="/wiki/Deforestation_in_the_Philippines" title="Deforestation in the Philippines">an acute problem in the Philippines</a>. Forest cover has declined from 70% of the Philippines's total land area in 1900 to about 18.3% in 1999.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[223]</a></sup> With an estimated 13,500 plant species in the country, 3,200 of which are unique to the islands,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet-228">[224]</a></sup> Philippine rainforests boast an array of flora,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-biodiverse_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-biodiverse-229">[225]</a></sup> including many rare <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_orchids_of_the_Philippines" title="List of the orchids of the Philippines">types of orchids</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[226]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Rafflesia" title="Rafflesia">rafflesia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[227]</a></sup>
</p><p>Around 1,100 land vertebrate species can be found in the Philippines including over 100 mammal species and 243 bird species not thought to exist elsewhere.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet_228-1"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet-228">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Allen2020_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-Allen2020-232">[228]</a></sup> The Philippines has among the highest rates of discovery in the world with sixteen new species of mammals discovered in the last ten years. Because of this, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_ecoregions_with_high_endemism" title="List of ecoregions with high endemism">rate of endemism</a> for the Philippines has risen and likely will continue to rise.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[229]</a></sup> Parts of its marine waters contain the highest diversity of shorefish species in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carpenter_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-Carpenter-234">[230]</a></sup>
</p><p>Large reptiles include the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_crocodile" title="Philippine crocodile">Philippine crocodile</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[231]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Saltwater_crocodile" title="Saltwater crocodile">saltwater crocodile</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[232]</a></sup> The largest crocodile in captivity, known locally as <a href="/wiki/Lolong" title="Lolong">Lolong</a>, was captured in the southern island of Mindanao,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[233]</a></sup> and died on February 10, 2013, from <a href="/wiki/Pneumonia" title="Pneumonia">pneumonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cardiac_arrest" title="Cardiac arrest">cardiac arrest</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[234]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_birds" title="List of national birds">national bird</a>, known as the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_eagle" title="Philippine eagle">Philippine eagle</a>, has the longest body of any eagle; it generally measures 86 to 102 cm (2.82 to 3.35 ft) in length and weighs 4.7 to 8.0 kg (10.4 to 17.6 lb).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RaptorsWorld_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-RaptorsWorld-239">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[236]</a></sup> The Philippine eagle is part of the family <a href="/wiki/Accipitridae" title="Accipitridae">Accipitridae</a> and is endemic to the rainforests of Luzon, Samar, Leyte, and Mindanao.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[237]</a></sup> The Philippines has the third highest number of endemic birds in the world (behind Indonesia and Australia) with 243 endemics. Notable birds include the <a href="/wiki/Celestial_monarch" title="Celestial monarch">Celestial monarch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flame-templed_babbler" title="Flame-templed babbler">flame-templed babbler</a>, <a href="/wiki/Red-vented_cockatoo" title="Red-vented cockatoo">Red-vented cockatoo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Whiskered_pitta" title="Whiskered pitta">Whiskered pitta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sulu_hornbill" title="Sulu hornbill">Sulu hornbill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rufous_hornbill" title="Rufous hornbill">Rufous hornbill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luzon_bleeding-heart" title="Luzon bleeding-heart">Luzon bleeding-heart</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Flame-breasted_fruit_dove" title="Flame-breasted fruit dove">Flame-breasted fruit dove</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Allen2020_232-1"><a href="#cite_note-Allen2020-232">[228]</a></sup>
</p><p>Philippine maritime waters produce unique and diverse marine life<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FAOOrg_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-FAOOrg-242">[238]</a></sup> and is an important part of the <a href="/wiki/Coral_Triangle" title="Coral Triangle">Coral Triangle</a> ecoregion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LiveScience-CoralTriangle_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-LiveScience-CoralTriangle-243">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PNAGovPH-PHSeeks_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-PNAGovPH-PHSeeks-244">[240]</a></sup> The total number of corals and marine fish species in this ecoregion is estimated at 500 and 2,400 respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet_228-2"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet-228">[224]</a></sup> New records<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[242]</a></sup> and species discoveries continue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[243]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[244]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[245]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tubbataha_Reef" title="Tubbataha Reef">Tubbataha Reef</a> in the Sulu Sea was declared a World Heritage Site in 1993.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[246]</a></sup> Philippine waters also sustain the cultivation of fish, crustaceans, oysters, and seaweeds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[247]</a></sup> One species of oyster, <a href="/wiki/Pinctada_maxima" title="Pinctada maxima">Pinctada maxima</a>, produces pearls that are naturally golden in color.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[248]</a></sup> Pearls have been declared a "national gem".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gem_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-gem-253">[249]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_the_Philippines" title="Climate of the Philippines">Climate of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="850" data-file-width="1203" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg/220px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg/330px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg/440px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> of the Philippines</div></div></div>
<p>The Philippines has a tropical maritime climate that is usually hot and humid. There are three seasons: a hot <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">dry season</a> from March to May; a <a href="/wiki/Wet_season" title="Wet season">rainy season</a> from June to November; and a cool dry season from December to February. The southwest <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> lasts from May to October and the northeast monsoon from November to April. Temperatures usually range from 21 °C (70 °F) to 32 °C (90 °F). The coolest month is January; the warmest is May.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PAGASA-Climate_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-PAGASA-Climate-254">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>The average yearly temperature is around 26.6 °C (79.9 °F). In considering temperature, location in terms of latitude and longitude is not a significant factor, and temperatures at sea level tend to be in the same range. Altitude usually has more of an impact. The average annual temperature of <a href="/wiki/Baguio" title="Baguio">Baguio</a> at an elevation of 1,500 meters (4,900 ft) above sea level is 18.3 °C (64.9 °F), making it a popular destination during hot summers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PAGASA-Climate_254-1"><a href="#cite_note-PAGASA-Climate-254">[250]</a></sup> Annual rainfall measures as much as 5,000 millimeters (200 in) in the mountainous east coast section but less than 1,000 millimeters (39 in) in some of the sheltered valleys.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-cp-255">[251]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sitting astride the <a href="/wiki/Typhoons_in_the_Philippines" title="Typhoons in the Philippines">typhoon belt</a>, the islands experience 15–20 typhoons annually from July to October,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_255-1"><a href="#cite_note-cp-255">[251]</a></sup> with around 19 typhoons<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[252]</a></sup> entering the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Area_of_Responsibility" title="Philippine Area of Responsibility">Philippine area of responsibility</a> in a typical year and 8 or 9 making landfall.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PagasaWMO_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-PagasaWMO-257">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-digitaltyphoon_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-digitaltyphoon-258">[254]</a></sup> Historically typhoons were sometimes referred to as <i>baguios</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[255]</a></sup> The wettest recorded typhoon to hit the Philippines dropped 2,210 millimeters (87 in) in Baguio from July 14 to 18, 1911.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[256]</a></sup> The Philippines is highly <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_Philippines" title="Climate change in the Philippines">exposed to climate change</a> and is among the world's ten countries that are most <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_vulnerability" title="Climate change vulnerability">vulnerable to climate change</a> risks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[257]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_Philippines" title="Politics of the Philippines">Politics of the Philippines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_Philippines" title="Government of the Philippines">Government of the Philippines</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Political_history_of_the_Philippines" title="Political history of the Philippines">Political history of the Philippines</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:124px;max-width:124px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:182px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ferdinand_R._Marcos_Jr_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="959" data-file-width="643" decoding="async" height="182" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Ferdinand_R._Marcos_Jr_%28cropped%29.jpg/122px-Ferdinand_R._Marcos_Jr_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Ferdinand_R._Marcos_Jr_%28cropped%29.jpg/183px-Ferdinand_R._Marcos_Jr_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Ferdinand_R._Marcos_Jr_%28cropped%29.jpg/244px-Ferdinand_R._Marcos_Jr_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="122"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">President</a><br/><a href="/wiki/Bongbong_Marcos" title="Bongbong Marcos">Bongbong Marcos</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:124px;max-width:124px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:182px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:VPSDPortrait.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="6000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/VPSDPortrait.jpg/122px-VPSDPortrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/VPSDPortrait.jpg/183px-VPSDPortrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/VPSDPortrait.jpg/244px-VPSDPortrait.jpg 2x" width="122"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_Philippines" title="Vice President of the Philippines">Vice President</a><br/><a href="/wiki/Sara_Duterte" title="Sara Duterte">Sara Duterte</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_(local_img).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="928" data-file-width="1650" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/20/Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28local_img%29.jpg/220px-Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28local_img%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/20/Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28local_img%29.jpg/330px-Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28local_img%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/20/Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28local_img%29.jpg/440px-Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28local_img%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_(local_img).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace" title="Malacañang Palace">Malacañang Palace</a> is the official residence of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">president of the Philippines</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Philippines has a <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democratic</a> government in the form of a constitutional <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rose-Ackerman_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rose-Ackerman-262">[258]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">president</a> functions as both <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-Banlaoi-263">[259]</a></sup> and is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Philippines" title="Armed Forces of the Philippines">armed forces</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rose-Ackerman_262-1"><a href="#cite_note-Rose-Ackerman-262">[258]</a></sup> The president <a href="/wiki/Presidential_elections_in_the_Philippines" title="Presidential elections in the Philippines">is elected</a> by <a href="/wiki/Direct_election" title="Direct election">direct election</a> for a single six-year term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TeehankeeThompson_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-TeehankeeThompson-264">[260]</a></sup> The president appoints and presides over the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_(government)" title="Cabinet (government)">cabinet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lazo_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lazo-265">[261]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 213–214">: 213–214 </span></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_the_Philippines" title="Congress of the Philippines">Congress</a> is composed of the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_the_Philippines" title="Senate of the Philippines">Senate</a>, serving as the <a href="/wiki/Upper_house" title="Upper house">upper house</a>, with members elected to a six-year term, and the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_of_the_Philippines" title="House of Representatives of the Philippines">House of Representatives</a>, serving as the <a href="/wiki/Lower_house" title="Lower house">lower house</a>, with members elected to a three-year term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carter2010_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-Carter2010-266">[262]</a></sup> Philippine politics tends to be dominated by those with well-known names, such as members of <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_families_in_the_Philippines" title="List of political families in the Philippines">political dynasties</a> or celebrities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Celebrity_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-Celebrity-267">[263]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-David_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-David-268">[264]</a></sup>
</p><p>Senators are elected <a href="/wiki/At-large" title="At-large">at-large</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carter2010_266-1"><a href="#cite_note-Carter2010-266">[262]</a></sup> while the representatives are elected from both <a href="/wiki/Legislative_districts_of_the_Philippines" title="Legislative districts of the Philippines">legislative districts</a> and through <a href="/wiki/Party-list_representation_in_the_House_of_Representatives_of_the_Philippines" title="Party-list representation in the House of Representatives of the Philippines">sectoral representation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lazo_265-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lazo-265">[261]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 162–163">: 162–163 </span></sup> The judicial power is vested in the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" title="Supreme Court of the Philippines">Supreme Court</a>, composed of a <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_Philippines" title="Chief Justice of the Philippines">chief justice</a> as its presiding officer and fourteen <a href="/wiki/Associate_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" title="Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines">associate justices</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pangalangan_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pangalangan-269">[265]</a></sup> all of whom are appointed by the president from nominations submitted by the <a href="/wiki/Judicial_and_Bar_Council" title="Judicial and Bar Council">Judicial and Bar Council</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rose-Ackerman_262-2"><a href="#cite_note-Rose-Ackerman-262">[258]</a></sup>
</p><p>There have been <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_reform_in_the_Philippines" title="Constitutional reform in the Philippines">attempts to change</a> the government to a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary government</a> since the Ramos administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[266]</a></sup> There is a significant amount of <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_the_Philippines" title="Corruption in the Philippines">corruption in the Philippines</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[267]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[268]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[269]</a></sup> which some historians attribute to the system of governance put in place during the Spanish colonial period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[270]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_Philippines" title="Foreign relations of the Philippines">Foreign relations of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Biden_Marcos_meeting.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="653" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Biden_Marcos_meeting.jpg/220px-Biden_Marcos_meeting.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Biden_Marcos_meeting.jpg/330px-Biden_Marcos_meeting.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Biden_Marcos_meeting.jpg/440px-Biden_Marcos_meeting.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Biden_Marcos_meeting.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Bongbong_Marcos" title="Bongbong Marcos">President Bongbong Marcos</a> and U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> participate in a bilateral meeting in September 2022.</div></div></div>
<p>As a <a href="/wiki/Philippines_and_the_United_Nations" title="Philippines and the United Nations">founding and active member</a> of the United Nations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[271]</a></sup> the country has been elected to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">Security Council</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[272]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Carlos_P._Romulo" title="Carlos P. Romulo">Carlos P. Romulo</a> was a former president of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="United Nations General Assembly">United Nations General Assembly</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[273]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[274]</a></sup> The country is an active participant in <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> missions, particularly in <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Transitional_Administration_in_East_Timor" title="United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor">East Timor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[276]</a></sup> Over 10 million Filipinos live and work overseas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-poea_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-poea-281">[277]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CFO2013_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-CFO2013-282">[278]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Philippines is a founding and active member of <a href="/wiki/ASEAN" title="ASEAN">ASEAN</a> (Association of Southeast Asian Nations).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-summit_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-summit-283">[279]</a></sup> It has hosted several <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Summit" title="ASEAN Summit">summits</a> and is an active contributor to the direction and policies of the bloc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[280]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[281]</a></sup> It is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[282]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_24" title="Group of 24">Group of 24</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-APEC2022_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-APEC2022-287">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BSPG24_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-BSPG24-288">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NonAlignedPH_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-NonAlignedPH-289">[285]</a></sup>  The country is also seeking to obtain observer status in the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[286]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[287]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Philippines has a long <a href="/wiki/Philippines%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Philippines–United States relations">relationship with the United States</a>, covering economics, security, and people-to-people relations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhilState_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-PhilState-292">[288]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Mutual_Defense_Treaty_(United_States%E2%80%93Philippines)" title="Mutual Defense Treaty (United States–Philippines)">Mutual Defense Treaty</a> between the two countries was signed in 1951 and supplemented with the <a href="/wiki/Philippines%E2%80%93United_States_Visiting_Forces_Agreement" title="Philippines–United States Visiting Forces Agreement">1999 Visiting Forces Agreement</a> and the 2016 <a href="/wiki/Enhanced_Defense_Cooperation_Agreement" title="Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement">Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[289]</a></sup> The Philippines supported American policies during the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> and participated in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam</a> wars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[291]</a></sup> In 2003 the Philippines was designated a <a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">major non-NATO ally</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[292]</a></sup> Under President Duterte, ties with the United States have weakened<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[293]</a></sup> with military purchases instead coming from China and Russia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[294]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[295]</a></sup> while Duterte states that the Philippines will no longer participate in any U.S.-led wars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[296]</a></sup> In 2021, it was revealed the United States would defend the Philippines including the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[297]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Philippines attaches great importance to its <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Philippines_relations" title="China–Philippines relations">relations with China</a> and has established significant cooperation with the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[298]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[302]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[303]</a></sup> Japan is the biggest bilateral contributor of <a href="/wiki/Official_development_assistance" title="Official development assistance">official development assistance</a> to the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[304]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[306]</a></sup> Although historical tensions exist because of the events of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, much of the animosity has faded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-neighbors_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-neighbors-311">[307]</a></sup> Historical and cultural ties continue to affect <a href="/wiki/Philippines%E2%80%93Spain_relations" title="Philippines–Spain relations">relations with Spain</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[308]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[309]</a></sup> Relations with Middle Eastern countries are shaped by the high number of Filipinos working in these countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[310]</a></sup> and by issues related to the Muslim minority in the Philippines;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[311]</a></sup> concerns have been raised regarding issues such as domestic abuse and war affecting<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[312]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bulatlat_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-bulatlat-317">[313]</a></sup> the approximately 2.5 million overseas Filipino workers in the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[314]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Philippines <a href="/wiki/Spratly_Islands_dispute" title="Spratly Islands dispute">has claims</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Spratly_Islands" title="Spratly Islands">Spratly Islands</a> which overlap with claims by China, Malaysia, Taiwan, and Vietnam. The largest of its controlled islands in <a href="/wiki/Thitu_Island" title="Thitu Island">Thitu Island</a>, which contains the Philippines's smallest village.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pitlo_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pitlo-319">[315]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[316]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Scarborough_Shoal" title="Scarborough Shoal">Scarborough Shoal</a> <a href="/wiki/Scarborough_Shoal_standoff" title="Scarborough Shoal standoff">standoff in 2012</a>, where China took control of the shoal from the Philippines, led to an <a href="/wiki/Philippines_v._China" title="Philippines v. China">international arbitration case</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[317]</a></sup> and has made the shoal a prominent symbol in the wider dispute.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[318]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Philippines" title="Armed Forces of the Philippines">Armed Forces of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3675" data-file-width="5145" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg/220px-BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg/330px-BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg/440px-BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/BRP_Jose_Rizal_(FF-150)" title="BRP Jose Rizal (FF-150)">BRP Jose Rizal (FF-150)</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Lead_ship" title="Lead ship">lead ship</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jose_Rizal-class_frigate" title="Jose Rizal-class frigate">her class</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guided_missile_frigate" title="Guided missile frigate">guided missile frigates</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Navy" title="Philippine Navy">Philippine Navy</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) consist of three branches: the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Air_Force" title="Philippine Air Force">Philippine Air Force</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Army" title="Philippine Army">Philippine Army</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Navy" title="Philippine Navy">Philippine Navy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-afporg_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-afporg-323">[319]</a></sup> The AFP is a <a href="/wiki/Volunteer_military" title="Volunteer military">volunteer force</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[320]</a></sup> Civilian security is handled by the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_National_Police" title="Philippine National Police">Philippine National Police</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_the_Interior_and_Local_Government" title="Department of the Interior and Local Government">Department of the Interior and Local Government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[321]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RA6975_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-RA6975-326">[322]</a></sup> As of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, $2.843 billion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[323]</a></sup> or 1.1 percent of GDP is spent on military forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[324]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Bangsamoro, the largest separatist organizations, the <a href="/wiki/Moro_National_Liberation_Front" title="Moro National Liberation Front">Moro National Liberation Front</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Moro_Islamic_Liberation_Front" title="Moro Islamic Liberation Front">Moro Islamic Liberation Front</a>, were engaging the government politically in the 2000's.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[325]</a></sup> Other more militant groups like the <a href="/wiki/Abu_Sayyaf" title="Abu Sayyaf">Abu Sayyaf</a> have kidnapped foreigners for ransom, particularly in the Sulu Archipelago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[327]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[329]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[330]</a></sup> Their presence decreased through successful security provided by the Philippine government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[331]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[332]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Philippines" title="Communist Party of the Philippines">Communist Party of the Philippines</a> and its military wing, the <a href="/wiki/New_People%27s_Army" title="New People's Army">New People's Army</a>, have been waging <a href="/wiki/Communist_rebellion_in_the_Philippines" title="Communist rebellion in the Philippines">guerrilla warfare</a> against the government since the 1970's, reaching its apex in 1986, when communist guerrillas gained control of a fifth of the country's territory before significantly dwindling militarily and politically after the return of democracy in 1986.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[333]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[334]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_the_Philippines" title="Administrative divisions of the Philippines">Administrative divisions of the Philippines</a></div>
<p>The Philippines is governed as a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a>, with the exception of the <a href="/wiki/Bangsamoro" title="Bangsamoro">Bangsamoro</a> Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[335]</a></sup> although there have been several steps towards decentralization within the unitary framework.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[337]</a></sup> A 1991 law devolved some powers to <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_the_Philippines" title="Local government in the Philippines">local governments</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atienza_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-Atienza-342">[338]</a></sup> The country is divided into 17 <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_the_Philippines" title="Regions of the Philippines">regions</a>, 81 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_the_Philippines" title="Provinces of the Philippines">provinces</a>, 146 <a href="/wiki/Cities_of_the_Philippines" title="Cities of the Philippines">cities</a>, 1,488 <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Philippines" title="Municipalities of the Philippines">municipalities</a>, and 42,036 <a href="/wiki/Barangay" title="Barangay">barangays</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[339]</a></sup> Regions other than Bangsamoro serve primarily to organize the provinces of the country for administrative convenience.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tusalem_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tusalem-344">[340]</a></sup> As of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, <a href="/wiki/Calabarzon" title="Calabarzon">Calabarzon</a> was the most populated region while the <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">National Capital Region</a> (NCR) was the most densely populated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-psa.gov.ph_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-psa.gov.ph-345">[341]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:502px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ph_regions_and_provinces.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6105" data-file-width="4200" decoding="async" height="727" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Ph_regions_and_provinces.svg/500px-Ph_regions_and_provinces.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Ph_regions_and_provinces.svg/750px-Ph_regions_and_provinces.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Ph_regions_and_provinces.svg/1000px-Ph_regions_and_provinces.svg.png 2x" width="500"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ph_regions_and_provinces.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Administrative map of the Philippines</div></div></div></div>

<tr>
<th scope="row">Region IV-A
</th>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Calabarzon" title="Calabarzon">Calabarzon</a>
</td>

<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_the_Philippines" title="Demographics of the Philippines">Demographics of the Philippines</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_Philippines" title="List of cities in the Philippines">List of cities in the Philippines</a></div>
<p>The Commission on Population estimated the country's population to be 107,190,081 as of December 31, 2018, based on the latest population census of 2015 conducted by the Philippine Statistics Authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Philippines_Estimated_2018_Population_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-Philippines_Estimated_2018_Population-348">[344]</a></sup> The population increased from 1990 to 2008 by approximately 28 million, a 45% growth in that time frame.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IEApop2011_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-IEApop2011-349">[345]</a></sup> The first <a href="/wiki/Census_in_the_Philippines" title="Census in the Philippines">official census</a> in the Philippines was carried out in 1877 and recorded a population of 5,567,685.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[346]</a></sup>
</p><p>A third of the population resides in <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a> and its immediately neighboring regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Officialpop_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-Officialpop-351">[347]</a></sup> The 2.34% average annual population growth rate between 1990 and 2000 decreased to an estimated 1.90% for the 2000–2010 period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[348]</a></sup> Government attempts to reduce population growth have been a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reproductive_Health_Bill_(Philippines)" title="Reproductive Health Bill (Philippines)">contentious issue</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gma_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-gma-353">[349]</a></sup> The population's median age is 22.7 years with 60.9% aged from 15 to 64 years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-8">[6]</a></sup> Life expectancy at birth is 69.4 years, 73.1 years for females and 65.9 years for males.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldfactbook1_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-worldfactbook1-354">[350]</a></sup> Poverty incidence dropped to 21.6% in 2015 from 25.2% in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-phpovertyincidence_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-phpovertyincidence-355">[351]</a></sup>
</p><p>The capital city of the Philippines is <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> and the most populous city is <a href="/wiki/Quezon_City" title="Quezon City">Quezon City</a>, both within the single urban area of <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[352]</a></sup> Metro Manila is the most populous of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_the_Philippines" title="List of metropolitan areas in the Philippines">3 defined metropolitan areas</a> in the Philippines<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[353]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities" title="List of largest cities">5th most populous</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-demographia_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-demographia-358">[354]</a></sup> Census data from 2015 showed it had a population of 12,877,253 constituting almost 13% of the national population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-phcensus_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-phcensus-359">[355]</a></sup> Including suburbs in the adjacent provinces (<a href="/wiki/Bulacan" title="Bulacan">Bulacan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cavite" title="Cavite">Cavite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laguna_(province)" title="Laguna (province)">Laguna</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rizal" title="Rizal">Rizal</a>) of <a href="/wiki/Greater_Manila_Area" title="Greater Manila Area">Greater Manila</a>, the population is around 23,088,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-demographia_358-1"><a href="#cite_note-demographia-358">[354]</a></sup> Across the country, the Philippines has a total urbanization rate of 51.2%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-phcensus_359-1"><a href="#cite_note-phcensus-359">[355]</a></sup> Metro Manila's <a href="/wiki/Gross_regional_product" title="Gross regional product">gross regional product</a> was estimated as of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> to be <a href="/wiki/Philippine_peso" title="Philippine peso">₱</a>468.4 billion (at constant 1985 prices) and accounts for 33% of the nation's GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NSCB_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-NSCB-360">[356]</a></sup> In 2011 Manila ranked as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP" title="List of cities by GDP">28th wealthiest urban agglomeration</a> in the world and the second in Southeast Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pwc_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-pwc-361">[357]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_the_Philippines" title="Ethnic groups in the Philippines">Ethnic groups in the Philippines</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Filipinos" title="Filipinos">Filipinos</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2863" data-file-width="1846" decoding="async" height="341" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg/220px-Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg/330px-Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg/440px-Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Dominant ethnic groups by province</div></div></div>
<p>There is substantial ethnic diversity with the Philippines, a product of the seas and mountain ranges dividing the archipelago along with significant foreign influences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-1"><a href="#cite_note-Banlaoi-263">[259]</a></sup> According to the 2010 census, 24.4% of <a href="/wiki/Filipinos" title="Filipinos">Filipinos</a> are <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_people" title="Tagalog people">Tagalog</a>, 11.4% <a href="/wiki/Visayans" title="Visayans">Visayans</a>/<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bisaya" title="Bisaya">Bisaya</a> (excluding <a href="/wiki/Cebuano_people" title="Cebuano people">Cebuano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hiligaynon_people" title="Hiligaynon people">Hiligaynon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Waray_people" title="Waray people">Waray</a>), 9.9% Cebuano, 8.8% <a href="/wiki/Ilocano_people" title="Ilocano people">Ilocano</a>, 8.4% Hiligaynon, 6.8% <a href="/wiki/Bicolano_people" title="Bicolano people">Bikol</a>, 4% Waray, and 26.2% are "others",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_8-2"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-8">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[358]</a></sup> which can be broken down further to yield more distinct nontribal groups like the <a href="/wiki/Moro_people" title="Moro people">Moro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kapampangan_people" title="Kapampangan people">Kapampangan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pangasinan_people" title="Pangasinan people">Pangasinense</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ibanag_people" title="Ibanag people">Ibanag</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ivatan_people" title="Ivatan people">Ivatan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[359]</a></sup> There are also <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Philippines" title="Indigenous peoples of the Philippines">indigenous peoples</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnol_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnol-364">[360]</a></sup> like the <a href="/wiki/Igorot_people" title="Igorot people">Igorot</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AcabadoPericolonialism_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-AcabadoPericolonialism-365">[361]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Lumad" title="Lumad">Lumad</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[362]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Mangyan" title="Mangyan">Mangyan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[363]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Sama-Bajau" title="Sama-Bajau">Bajau</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[364]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Peoples_of_Palawan" title="Peoples of Palawan">tribes of Palawan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-camperspoint_tribes_370-0"><a href="#cite_note-camperspoint_tribes-370">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Negrito" title="Negrito">Negritos</a> are considered among the earliest inhabitants of the islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Negritos_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-Negritos-371">[367]</a></sup> These minority aboriginal settlers are an <a href="/wiki/Australo-Melanesian" title="Australo-Melanesian">Australoid</a> group and are left over from the first human migration out of Africa to Australia and were likely displaced by later waves of migration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[368]</a></sup> At least some Negritos in the Philippines have <a href="/wiki/Denisovan" title="Denisovan">Denisovan</a> admixture in their genomes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[370]</a></sup> Ethnic Filipinos generally belong to several Southeast Asian ethnic groups classified linguistically as part of the <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_peoples" title="Austronesian peoples">Austronesian</a> or <a href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian_languages" title="Malayo-Polynesian languages">Malayo-Polynesian</a> speaking people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnol_364-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnol-364">[360]</a></sup> There is some uncertainty over the origin of this Austronesian speaking population. It is likely that ancestors related to <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_indigenous_peoples" title="Taiwanese indigenous peoples">Taiwanese aborigines</a> brought their language and mixed with existing populations in the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AJHG_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-AJHG-375">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[372]</a></sup> The Lumad and Sama-Bajau ethnic groups have ancestral affinity with the <a href="/wiki/Austroasiatic_languages" title="Austroasiatic languages">Austroasiatic</a> <a href="/wiki/Mlabri_language" title="Mlabri language">Mlabri</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lua_people" title="Lua people">Htin</a> peoples of mainland Southeast Asia. There was a westward expansion of Papuan ancestry from <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a> to eastern Indonesia and Mindanao detected among the <a href="/wiki/Blaan_people" title="Blaan people">Blaan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sangirese_language" title="Sangirese language">Sangir</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Larena_38-1"><a href="#cite_note-Larena-38">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under Spanish rule there was some immigration from elsewhere in the empire, especially <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Asian" title="Latin American Asian">from the Spanish Americas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mawson_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mawson-377">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UnrulyMexicans_78-1"><a href="#cite_note-UnrulyMexicans-78">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[374]</a></sup> In relation to these,  the <a href="/wiki/National_Geographic" title="National Geographic">National Geographic</a> project concluded in 2016 that people living in the Philippine archipelago carried <a href="/wiki/Genetic_marker" title="Genetic marker">genetic markers</a> in the following percentages: 53% <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a>, 36% <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">Eastern Asia</a>, 5% Southern <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, 3% <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">Southern Asia</a>, and 2% Native American<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[375]</a></sup> (From <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UnrulyMexicans_78-2"><a href="#cite_note-UnrulyMexicans-78">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ethnolinguistic_map_of_the_Philippines.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3458" data-file-width="5000" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Ethnolinguistic_map_of_the_Philippines.png/220px-Ethnolinguistic_map_of_the_Philippines.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Ethnolinguistic_map_of_the_Philippines.png/330px-Ethnolinguistic_map_of_the_Philippines.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Ethnolinguistic_map_of_the_Philippines.png/440px-Ethnolinguistic_map_of_the_Philippines.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ethnolinguistic_map_of_the_Philippines.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A map that shows all ethnolinguistic groups in the Philippines.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Chinese_Filipino" title="Chinese Filipino">Chinese Filipinos</a> are mostly the descendants of immigrants from <a href="/wiki/Fujian" title="Fujian">Fujian</a> in China after 1898,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[376]</a></sup> numbering around 2 million, although there are an estimated 20% of Filipinos who have partial Chinese ancestry, stemming from precolonial and colonial Chinese migrants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[377]</a></sup> While a distinct minority, Chinese Filipinos are well integrated into Filipino society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-2"><a href="#cite_note-Banlaoi-263">[259]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[378]</a></sup> As of 2015, there are 220,000 to 600,000 <a href="/wiki/Americans" title="Americans">American citizens</a> living in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[379]</a></sup> There are also up to 250,000 <a href="/wiki/Amerasian" title="Amerasian">Amerasians</a> scattered across the cities of <a href="/wiki/Angeles_City" title="Angeles City">Angeles</a>, Manila, and <a href="/wiki/Olongapo" title="Olongapo">Olongapo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[380]</a></sup> Other important non-indigenous minorities include <a href="/wiki/Indian_Filipino" title="Indian Filipino">Indians</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[382]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_the_Philippines" title="Arabs in the Philippines">Arabs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[383]</a></sup> There are also <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">Japanese people</a>, which include escaped Christians (<a href="/wiki/Kirishitan" title="Kirishitan">Kirishitan</a>) who <a href="/wiki/Martyrs_of_Japan" title="Martyrs of Japan">fled the persecutions of Shogun Tokugawa Ieyasu</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[384]</a></sup> The descendants of mixed-race couples are known as <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filipino_mestizo" title="Filipino mestizo">Tisoy</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[385]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_Philippines" title="Languages of the Philippines">Languages of the Philippines</a></div>
<table class="wikitable sortable floatright" style="text-align:right; font-size:90%; background:white;">

</td></tr>
<tr class="sortbottom" style="border-top:double gray;">
<th colspan="3" scope="col" style="text-align:left;letter-spacing:0.02em;">TOTAL
</th>
<th scope="col" style="text-align:right;">92,097,978
</th></tr>
<tr class="sortbottom">
<td colspan="4" style="font-style:italic;">Source: <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Statistics_Authority" title="Philippine Statistics Authority">Philippine Statistics Authority</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhilippine_Statistics_Authority201429–34_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhilippine_Statistics_Authority201429–34-390">[386]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">Ethnologue</a></i> lists 186 individual languages in the Philippines, 182 of which are living languages, while 4 no longer have any known speakers. Most native languages are part of the Philippine branch of the <a href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian_languages" title="Malayo-Polynesian languages">Malayo-Polynesian languages</a>, which is a branch of the <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian language family</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnol_364-2"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnol-364">[360]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dyen1965_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dyen1965-391">[387]</a></sup> In addition, various Spanish-based creole varieties collectively called <a href="/wiki/Chavacano" title="Chavacano">Chavacano</a> exist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[388]</a></sup> There are also many <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Negrito_languages#Unique_vocabulary" title="Philippine Negrito languages">Philippine Negrito languages</a> that have unique vocabularies that survived Austronesian acculturation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[389]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Filipino_language" title="Filipino language">Filipino</a> and <a href="/wiki/Philippine_English" title="Philippine English">English</a> are the official languages of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OfficialLang_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-OfficialLang-394">[390]</a></sup> Filipino is a standardized version of <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">Tagalog</a>, spoken mainly in Metro Manila.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[391]</a></sup> Both Filipino and English are used in government, education, print, broadcast media, and business, with third local languages often being used at the same time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BrownGanguly2003_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-BrownGanguly2003-396">[392]</a></sup> The Philippine constitution provides for the promotion of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_Philippines" title="Spanish language in the Philippines">Spanish</a> and Arabic on a voluntary and optional basis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OfficialLang_394-1"><a href="#cite_note-OfficialLang-394">[390]</a></sup> Spanish, which was widely used as a lingua franca in the late nineteenth century, has since declined greatly in use,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stewart2012_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-Stewart2012-397">[393]</a></sup> although Spanish <a href="/wiki/Loanword" title="Loanword">loanwords</a> are still present today in Philippine languages,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[395]</a></sup> while Arabic is mainly taught in Islamic schools in Mindanao.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[396]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nineteen regional languages act as auxiliary official languages used as media of instruction: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aklan_language" title="Aklan language">Aklanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bikol_languages" title="Bikol languages">Bikol</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cebuano_language" title="Cebuano language">Cebuano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chavacano" title="Chavacano">Chavacano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hiligaynon_language" title="Hiligaynon language">Hiligaynon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ibanag_language" title="Ibanag language">Ibanag</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ilocano_language" title="Ilocano language">Ilocano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivatan_language" title="Ivatan language">Ivatan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kapampangan_language" title="Kapampangan language">Kapampangan</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kinaray-a_language" title="Kinaray-a language">Kinaray-a</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maguindanao_language" title="Maguindanao language">Maguindanao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maranao_language" title="Maranao language">Maranao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pangasinan_language" title="Pangasinan language">Pangasinan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sambal_language" title="Sambal language">Sambal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Surigaonon_language" title="Surigaonon language">Surigaonon</a>, Tagalog, <a href="/wiki/Tausug_language" title="Tausug language">Tausug</a>, <a href="/wiki/Waray_language" title="Waray language">Waray</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yakan_language" title="Yakan language">Yakan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7_mother_languages_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-7_mother_languages-5">[4]</a></sup> Other indigenous languages such as, <a href="/wiki/Cuyonon_language" title="Cuyonon language">Cuyonon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ifugao_language" title="Ifugao language">Ifugao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Itbayat_language" title="Itbayat language">Itbayat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kalinga_language" title="Kalinga language">Kalinga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kamayo_language" title="Kamayo language">Kamayo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kankanaey_language" title="Kankanaey language">Kankanaey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Masbate%C3%B1o_language" title="Masbateño language">Masbateño</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romblomanon_language" title="Romblomanon language">Romblomanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manobo_languages" title="Manobo languages">Manobo</a>, and several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Visayan_languages" title="Visayan languages">Visayan languages</a> are prevalent in their respective provinces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethn_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-ethn-401">[397]</a></sup> Article 3 of Republic Act No. 11106 declared the <a href="/wiki/Filipino_Sign_Language" title="Filipino Sign Language">Filipino Sign Language</a> as the national sign language of the Philippines, specifying that it shall be recognized, supported and promoted as the medium of official communication in all transactions involving the deaf, and as the language of instruction of deaf education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[398]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[399]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_the_Philippines" title="Religion in the Philippines">Religion in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg/220px-St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg/330px-St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg/440px-St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The historical <a href="/wiki/Paoay_Church" title="Paoay Church">Paoay Church</a> in Ilocos Norte. Declared as a National Cultural Treasure by the Philippine government in 1973 and a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a> under the collective group of <a href="/wiki/Baroque_Churches_of_the_Philippines" title="Baroque Churches of the Philippines">Baroque Churches of the Philippines</a> in 1993.</div></div></div>
<p>The Philippines is a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a> which protects <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_the_Philippines" title="Freedom of religion in the Philippines">freedom of religion</a>. <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_Philippines" title="Christianity in the Philippines">Christianity</a> is the dominant faith,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013ReportonInternationalReligiousFreedom_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-2013ReportonInternationalReligiousFreedom-404">[400]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReligiousFreedomon2014_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReligiousFreedomon2014-405">[401]</a></sup> shared by about 89% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PSA2019_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-PSA2019-406">[402]</a></sup> As of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country had the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">world's third largest Roman Catholic population</a>, and was the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Asia" title="Christianity in Asia">largest Christian nation in Asia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[403]</a></sup> Census data from 2015 found that about 79.53% of the population professed <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_the_Philippines" title="Catholic Church in the Philippines">Catholicism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015census_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-408">[404]</a></sup> Around 37% of the population regularly attend <a href="/wiki/Mass_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Mass in the Catholic Church">Mass</a>. 29% of self-identified Catholics consider themselves very religious.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newsinfo.inquirer.net_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-newsinfo.inquirer.net-409">[405]</a></sup> An <a href="/wiki/Independent_Catholicism" title="Independent Catholicism">independent Catholic</a> church, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Independent_Church" title="Philippine Independent Church">Philippine Independent Church</a>, has around 66,959 adherents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015census_408-1"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-408">[404]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_the_Philippines" title="Protestantism in the Philippines">Protestants</a> were 9.13% of the population in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[406]</a></sup> 2.64% of the population are members of <a href="/wiki/Iglesia_ni_Cristo" title="Iglesia ni Cristo">Iglesia ni Cristo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015census_408-2"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-408">[404]</a></sup> The combined following of the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Council_of_Evangelical_Churches" title="Philippine Council of Evangelical Churches">Philippine Council of Evangelical Churches</a> comes to 2.42% of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015census_408-3"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-408">[404]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[407]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Islam_in_the_Philippines" title="Islam in the Philippines">Islam</a> is the second largest religion. The Muslim population of the Philippines was reported as 6.01% of the total population according to census returns in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015census_408-4"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-408">[404]</a></sup> Conversely, a 2012 report by the National Commission of Muslim Filipinos stated that about 10,700,000 or 11% of Filipinos are Muslims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013ReportonInternationalReligiousFreedom_404-1"><a href="#cite_note-2013ReportonInternationalReligiousFreedom-404">[400]</a></sup> The majority of Muslims live in Mindanao and nearby islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReligiousFreedomon2014_405-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReligiousFreedomon2014-405">[401]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[408]</a></sup> Most practice <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Shafi%27i_school" title="Shafi'i school">Shafi'i school</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[409]</a></sup>
</p><p>The percentage of combined <a href="/wiki/Negative_and_positive_atheism" title="Negative and positive atheism">positive atheist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">agnostic</a> people in the Philippines was about 3% of the population as of 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[410]</a></sup> The 2015 Philippine Census reported the religion of about 0.02% of the population as "none".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015census_408-5"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-408">[404]</a></sup> A 2014 survey by <a href="/wiki/Gallup_International_Association" title="Gallup International Association">Gallup International Association</a> reported that 21% of its respondents identify as "not a religious person".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[411]</a></sup> Around 0.24% of the population practice <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_Philippine_folk_religions" title="Indigenous Philippine folk religions">indigenous Philippine folk religions</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015census_408-6"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-408">[404]</a></sup> whose practices and folk beliefs are often syncretized with Christianity and Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[413]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_Philippines" title="Buddhism in the Philippines">Buddhism</a> is practiced by around 0.03% of the population,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015census_408-7"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-408">[404]</a></sup> concentrated among Filipinos of Chinese descent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[414]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_the_Philippines" title="Health in the Philippines">Health in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:St._Luke%27s_Medical_Center_BGC_2021.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2251" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/bc/St._Luke%27s_Medical_Center_BGC_2021.jpg/220px-St._Luke%27s_Medical_Center_BGC_2021.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/bc/St._Luke%27s_Medical_Center_BGC_2021.jpg/330px-St._Luke%27s_Medical_Center_BGC_2021.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/bc/St._Luke%27s_Medical_Center_BGC_2021.jpg/440px-St._Luke%27s_Medical_Center_BGC_2021.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:St._Luke%27s_Medical_Center_BGC_2021.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/St._Luke%27s_Medical_Center_%E2%80%93_Global_City" title="St. Luke's Medical Center – Global City">St. Luke's Medical Center</a> in Taguig.</div></div></div>
<p>In 2016, 63.1% of healthcare came from private expenditures while 36.9% was from the government (12.4% from the national government, 7.1% from the local government, and 17.4% from social health insurance).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_2_(pages_25-27)_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_2_(pages_25-27)-419">[415]</a></sup> Total health expenditure share in GDP for the year 2016 was 4.5%.
