Per capita health expenditure rate in 2015 was <span style="white-space: nowrap"><a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US$</a>323</span>, which was one of the lowest in Southeast Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_2_(page_23)_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_2_(page_23)-420">[416]</a></sup> The budget allocation for Healthcare in 2019 was ₱98.6 billion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[417]</a></sup> and had an increase in budget in 2014 with a record high in the collection of taxes from the House Bill 5727 (commonly known as <a href="/wiki/Sin_tax" title="Sin tax">Sin tax</a> Bill).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[418]</a></sup>
</p><p>There were 101,688 hospital beds in the country in 2016, with government hospital beds accounting for 47% and private hospital beds for 53%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_60)_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_60)-423">[419]</a></sup>
In 2009, there were an estimated 90,370 physicians or 1 per every 833 people, 480,910 nurses and 43,220 dentists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WHOStats2009_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-WHOStats2009-424">[420]</a></sup> Retention of skilled practitioners is a problem. Seventy percent of nursing graduates go overseas to work. As of 2007<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the Philippines was the largest supplier of nurses for export.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[421]</a></sup> The Philippines suffers a triple burden of high levels of communicable diseases, high levels of non-communicable diseases, and high exposure to natural disasters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[422]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2018, there were 1,258 hospitals licensed by the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Health_(Philippines)" title="Department of Health (Philippines)">Department of Health</a>, of which 433 <span style="font-size:inherit">(<span data-sort-value="7,001,344,197,138,315,000♠" style="display:none"></span>34%)</span> were government-run and 825 <span style="font-size:inherit">(<span data-sort-value="7,001,655,802,861,685,000♠" style="display:none"></span>66%)</span> private.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[423]</a></sup> A total of 20,065 barangay health stations and 2,590 rural health units provide primary care services throughout the country as of 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_58)_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_58)-428">[424]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_diseases" title="Cardiovascular diseases">Cardiovascular diseases</a> account for more than 35% of all deaths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[425]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[426]</a></sup> 9,264 cases of <a href="/wiki/HIV" title="HIV">HIV</a> were reported for the year 2016, with 8,151 being asymptomatic cases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3.2_(page_47)_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3.2_(page_47)-431">[427]</a></sup> At the time the country was considered a low-HIV-prevalence country, with less than 0.1% of the adult population estimated to be HIV-positive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[428]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/HIV/AIDS" title="HIV/AIDS">HIV/AIDS</a> cases increased from 12,000 in 2005<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-usaidhealth_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-usaidhealth-433">[429]</a></sup> to 39,622 as of 2016, with 35,957 being asymptomatic cases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3.2_(page_47)_431-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3.2_(page_47)-431">[427]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is improvement in patients access to medicines due to Filipinos' growing acceptance of <a href="/wiki/Generic_drug" title="Generic drug">generic drugs</a>, with 6 out of 10 Filipinos already using generics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3_(page_58)_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3_(page_58)-434">[430]</a></sup> While the country's <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> implementation is underway as spearheaded by the state-owned <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Health_Insurance_Corporation" title="Philippine Health Insurance Corporation">Philippine Health Insurance Corporation</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[431]</a></sup> most healthcare-related expenses are either borne out of pocket<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[432]</a></sup> or through health maintenance organization (HMO)-provided health plans. As of April 2020, there are only about 7 million individuals covered by these plans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[433]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_Philippines" title="Education in the Philippines">Education in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Main_Bulding_of_the_University_of_Santo_Tomas.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1620" data-file-width="2858" decoding="async" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Main_Bulding_of_the_University_of_Santo_Tomas.jpg/220px-Main_Bulding_of_the_University_of_Santo_Tomas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Main_Bulding_of_the_University_of_Santo_Tomas.jpg/330px-Main_Bulding_of_the_University_of_Santo_Tomas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Main_Bulding_of_the_University_of_Santo_Tomas.jpg/440px-Main_Bulding_of_the_University_of_Santo_Tomas.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Main_Bulding_of_the_University_of_Santo_Tomas.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Founded in 1611, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Santo_Tomas" title="University of Santo Tomas">University of Santo Tomas</a> is the oldest extant university in Asia.</div></div></div>
<p>The Philippines had a simple <a href="/wiki/Literacy" title="Literacy">literacy</a> rate of 98.3% as of 2015, and a <a href="/wiki/Functional_illiteracy" title="Functional illiteracy">functional literacy</a> rate of 90.3% as of 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NQ-June2020_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-NQ-June2020-438">[434]</a></sup> Education takes up a significant proportion of the national budget. In the 2020 budget, education was allocated PHP17.1 billion from the PHP4.1 trillion budget.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[435]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Commission_on_Higher_Education_(Philippines)" title="Commission on Higher Education (Philippines)">Commission on Higher Education</a> lists 2,180 higher education institutions, among which 607 are public and 1,573 are private.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CHED_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-CHED-440">[436]</a></sup> Primary and secondary schooling is divided between a 6-year elementary period, a 4-year junior high school period, and a 2-year senior high school period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[438]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[439]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Education_(Philippines)" title="Department of Education (Philippines)">Department of Education</a> covers elementary, secondary, and non-formal education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[440]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Technical_Education_and_Skills_Development_Authority" title="Technical Education and Skills Development Authority">Technical Education and Skills Development Authority</a> administers middle-level education training and development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[441]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[442]</a></sup> The Commission on Higher Education was created in 1994 to, among other functions, formulate and recommend development plans, policies, priorities, and programs on <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_the_Philippines" title="Higher education in the Philippines">higher education</a> and research.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[443]</a></sup> In 2004, <a href="/wiki/Madrasa" title="Madrasa">madaris</a> were mainstreamed in 16 regions nationwide, mainly in Muslim areas in Mindanao under the auspices and program of the Department of Education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-madrasa_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-madrasa-448">[444]</a></sup>
</p><p>Public universities are all non-sectarian entities and are classified as State Universities and Colleges or Local Colleges and Universities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CHED_440-1"><a href="#cite_note-CHED-440">[436]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines" title="University of the Philippines">University of the Philippines</a>, a system of eight constituent universities, is the <a href="/wiki/National_university" title="National university">national university</a> system of the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Charter_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-Charter-449">[445]</a></sup> The country's top ranked universities are as follows: University of the Philippines, <a href="/wiki/Ateneo_de_Manila_University" title="Ateneo de Manila University">Ateneo de Manila University</a>, <a href="/wiki/De_La_Salle_University" title="De La Salle University">De La Salle University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/University_of_Santo_Tomas" title="University of Santo Tomas">University of Santo Tomas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[446]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[447]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[448]</a></sup> The University of Santo Tomas, established in 1611, has the oldest <a href="/wiki/Ancient_literature" title="Ancient literature">extant</a> university charter in the Philippines and Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[449]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[450]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_Philippines" title="Economy of the Philippines">Economy of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:307px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GPD_per_capita_development_of_the_Philippines.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="649" data-file-width="1025" decoding="async" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/GPD_per_capita_development_of_the_Philippines.jpg/305px-GPD_per_capita_development_of_the_Philippines.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/GPD_per_capita_development_of_the_Philippines.jpg/458px-GPD_per_capita_development_of_the_Philippines.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/GPD_per_capita_development_of_the_Philippines.jpg/610px-GPD_per_capita_development_of_the_Philippines.jpg 2x" width="305"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GPD_per_capita_development_of_the_Philippines.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Real GPD per capita development of the Philippines</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Philippines_Product_Exports_(2019).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Philippines_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/220px-Philippines_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Philippines_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/330px-Philippines_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Philippines_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/440px-Philippines_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Philippines_Product_Exports_(2019).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A proportional representation of Philippines exports, 2019</div></div></div>
<p>In 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the Philippine economy produced an estimated <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> (nominal) of $367.4 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dfat_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-dfat-455">[451]</a></sup> Primary exports in 2019 included integrated circuits, office machinery/parts, insulated wiring, semiconductors, transformers; major trading partners included China (16%), United States (15%), Japan (13%), Hong Kong (12%), Singapore (7%), Germany (5%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_8-3"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-8">[6]</a></sup> Its unit of <a href="/wiki/Currency" title="Currency">currency</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_peso" title="Philippine peso">Philippine peso</a> (₱<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[452]</a></sup> or PHP<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[453]</a></sup>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[454]</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FederalRegisterVol78_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-FederalRegisterVol78-459">[455]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[456]</a></sup> the Philippine economy has been transitioning from one based upon agriculture to an economy with more emphasis upon services and manufacturing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FederalRegisterVol78_459-1"><a href="#cite_note-FederalRegisterVol78-459">[455]</a></sup> Of the country's 2018 labor force of around 43.46 million, the <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_the_Philippines" title="Agriculture in the Philippines">agricultural sector</a> employed 24.3%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[457]</a></sup> and accounted for 8.1% of 2018 GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PSAGovPH-GDP2018_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-PSAGovPH-GDP2018-462">[458]</a></sup> The industrial sector employed around 19% of the workforce and accounted for 34.1% of GDP, while 57% of the workers involved in the services sector were responsible for 57.8% of GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PSAGovPH-GDP2018_462-1"><a href="#cite_note-PSAGovPH-GDP2018-462">[458]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[459]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unemployment_rate" title="Unemployment rate">unemployment rate</a> as of October 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, stands at 4.5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[460]</a></sup> The inflation rate eased to 1.7% in August 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[461]</a></sup> Gross international reserves as of October 2013 are $83.201 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[462]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Debt-to-GDP_ratio" title="Debt-to-GDP ratio">debt-to-GDP ratio</a> continues to decline to 37.6% as of the second quarter of 2019<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[463]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[464]</a></sup> from a record high of 78% in 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[465]</a></sup> The country is a net importer<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-quickstat_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-quickstat-470">[466]</a></sup> but is also a creditor nation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[467]</a></sup> Manila hosts the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Development_Bank" title="Asian Development Bank">Asian Development Bank</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[468]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG/220px-0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG/330px-0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG/440px-0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Filipinos planting rice. Agriculture employs 23% of the Filipino workforce as of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[469]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">1997 Asian financial crisis</a> affected the economy, resulting in a lingering decline of the value of the peso and falls in the stock market. The effects on the Philippines was not as severe as other Asian nations because of the <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_conservatism" title="Fiscal conservatism">fiscal conservatism</a> of the government, partly as a result of decades of monitoring and fiscal supervision from the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>, in comparison to the massive spending of its neighbors on the rapid acceleration of economic growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lastlaugh_159-1"><a href="#cite_note-lastlaugh-159">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Remittance" title="Remittance">Remittances</a> from <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Filipinos" title="Overseas Filipinos">overseas Filipinos</a> contribute significantly to the Philippine economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-InquirerOFW_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-InquirerOFW-474">[470]</a></sup> Remittances peaked in 2006 at 10.4% of the national GDP, and were 8.6% and 8.5% in 2012 and in 2014 respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-InquirerOFW_474-1"><a href="#cite_note-InquirerOFW-474">[470]</a></sup> In 2014 the total worth of foreign exchange remittances was US$28 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[471]</a></sup> Regional development is uneven, with Luzon – Metro Manila in particular – gaining most of the new economic growth at the expense of the other regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-econ-manila_476-0"><a href="#cite_note-econ-manila-476">[472]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[473]</a></sup>
</p><p>Service industries such as <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_the_Philippines" title="Tourism in the Philippines">tourism</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[474]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Business_process_outsourcing_in_the_Philippines" title="Business process outsourcing in the Philippines">business process outsourcing</a> (BPO) have been identified as areas with some of the best opportunities for growth for the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-atimesbpo_479-0"><a href="#cite_note-atimesbpo-479">[475]</a></sup> The business process outsourcing industry is composed of eight sub-sectors, namely, knowledge process outsourcing and back offices, animation, <a href="/wiki/Call_center_industry_in_the_Philippines" title="Call center industry in the Philippines">call centers</a>, software development, game development, engineering design, and <a href="/wiki/Medical_transcription" title="Medical transcription">medical transcription</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[476]</a></sup> In 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the Philippines was reported as having eclipsed India as the main center of BPO services in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[477]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[478]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[479]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_Philippines" title="Science and technology in the Philippines">Science and technology in the Philippines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Philippine_space_program" title="Philippine space program">Philippine space program</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">International Rice Research Institute</a> in <a href="/wiki/Los_Ba%C3%B1os,_Laguna" title="Los Baños, Laguna">Los Baños, Laguna</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Science_and_Technology_(Philippines)" title="Department of Science and Technology (Philippines)">Department of Science and Technology</a> is the governing agency responsible for the development of coordination of science and technology-related projects in the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[480]</a></sup> Research organizations in the country include the <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">International Rice Research Institute</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[481]</a></sup> which focuses on the development of new rice varieties and rice crop management techniques.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[482]</a></sup> The Philippines bought its first satellite in 1996.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[483]</a></sup> In 2016, the Philippines first micro-satellite, <a href="/wiki/Diwata-1" title="Diwata-1">Diwata-1</a>, was launched aboard the United States' <a href="/wiki/Cygnus_(spacecraft)" title="Cygnus (spacecraft)">Cygnus</a> spacecraft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Diwata-1_488-0"><a href="#cite_note-Diwata-1-488">[484]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Philippines has a high concentration of cellular phone users.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pldt_489-0"><a href="#cite_note-pldt-489">[485]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Text_messaging" title="Text messaging">Text messaging</a> is a popular form of communication and, in 2007, the nation sent an average of one billion <a href="/wiki/SMS" title="SMS">SMS</a> messages per day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[486]</a></sup> The country has a high level of mobile financial services utilization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-txt_491-0"><a href="#cite_note-txt-491">[487]</a></sup> The Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company, commonly known as <a href="/wiki/PLDT" title="PLDT">PLDT</a>, is a formerly nationalized telecommunications provider.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pldt_489-1"><a href="#cite_note-pldt-489">[485]</a></sup> It is also the largest company in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[488]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Telecommunications_Commission" title="National Telecommunications Commission">National Telecommunications Commission</a> is the agency responsible for the supervision, adjudication and control over all <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_the_Philippines" title="Telecommunications in the Philippines">telecommunications services throughout the country</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[489]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_the_Philippines" title="Tourism in the Philippines">Tourism in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Big_lagoon_entrance,_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1168" data-file-width="1752" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Big_lagoon_entrance,_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Limestone cliffs of <a href="/wiki/El_Nido,_Palawan" title="El Nido, Palawan">El Nido</a>, Palawan.</div></div></div>
<p>The travel and tourism sector contributed 10.6% of the country's GDP in 2015<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[490]</a></sup> and providing 1,226,500 jobs in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[491]</a></sup> 8,260,913 international visitors arrived from January to December 2019, up by 15.24% for the same period in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[492]</a></sup> <span data-sort-value="7001586227454519857♠" style="display:none"></span>58.62% (4,842,774) of these came from East Asia, <span data-sort-value="7001158389756677016♠" style="display:none"></span>15.84% (1,308,444) came from North America, and <span data-sort-value="7000637740646826809♠" style="display:none"></span>6.38% (526,832) came from other ASEAN countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NQ-June2020_438-1"><a href="#cite_note-NQ-June2020-438">[434]</a></sup> The island of <a href="/wiki/Boracay" title="Boracay">Boracay</a>, popular for its beaches, was named as the best island in the world by <i><a href="/wiki/Travel_%2B_Leisure" title="Travel + Leisure">Travel + Leisure</a></i> in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mb.com.ph_497-0"><a href="#cite_note-mb.com.ph-497">[493]</a></sup> The Philippines is a popular retirement destination for foreigners because of its climate and low cost of living.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[494]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="525" data-file-width="701" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg/220px-MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg/330px-MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg/440px-MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LRT_Line_2_(Metro_Manila)" title="LRT Line 2 (Metro Manila)">LRT Line 2</a> train at <a href="/wiki/Santolan_station_(LRT)" title="Santolan station (LRT)">Santolan station</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_the_Philippines" title="Transportation in the Philippines">Transportation in the Philippines</a> is facilitated by road, air, rail and waterways. As of December 2018, there are 210,528 kilometers (130,816 mi) of roads in the Philippines, with only 65,101 kilometers (40,452 mi) of roads paved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[495]</a></sup> The 919-kilometer (571 mi) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Strong_Republic_Nautical_Highway" title="Strong Republic Nautical Highway">Strong Republic Nautical Highway</a>, an integrated set of highway segments and ferry routes covering 17 cities, was established in 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[496]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pan-Philippine_Highway" title="Pan-Philippine Highway">Pan-Philippine Highway</a> connects the islands of Luzon, Samar, Leyte, and Mindanao, forming the backbone of land-based transportation in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[497]</a></sup> Roads are the dominant form of transport, carrying 98% of people and 58% of cargo. A <a href="/wiki/Philippine_expressway_network" title="Philippine expressway network">network of expressways</a> extends from the capital to other areas of Luzon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[498]</a></sup> The 8.25-kilometer (5.13 mi) <a href="/wiki/Cebu%E2%80%93Cordova_Link_Expressway" title="Cebu–Cordova Link Expressway">Cebu–Cordova Link Expressway</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cebu" title="Cebu">Cebu</a> opened in April 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[499]</a></sup> Traffic is a significant issue facing the country, especially <a href="/wiki/Traffic_in_Metro_Manila" title="Traffic in Metro Manila">within Manila</a> and on arterial roads connecting to the capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[500]</a></sup>
</p><p>Public transport in the country include buses, <a href="/wiki/Jeepney" title="Jeepney">jeepneys</a>, <a href="/wiki/UV_Express" title="UV Express">UV Express</a>, TNVS, Filcab, taxis, and <a href="/wiki/Motorized_tricycle_(Philippines)" title="Motorized tricycle (Philippines)">tricycles</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[501]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[502]</a></sup> Jeepneys are a popular and iconic public utility vehicle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reu1_507-0"><a href="#cite_note-reu1-507">[503]</a></sup> Jeepneys and other public utility vehicles which are older than 15 years are <a href="/wiki/Public_Utility_Vehicle_Modernization_Program" title="Public Utility Vehicle Modernization Program">being phased out gradually</a> in favor of a more efficient and environmentally friendly <a href="/wiki/European_emission_standards" title="European emission standards">Euro 4</a> compliant vehicles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[504]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[505]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite wider historical use, <a href="/wiki/Rail_transportation_in_the_Philippines" title="Rail transportation in the Philippines">rail transportation in the Philippines</a> is limited, being confined to transporting passengers within Metro Manila, and the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Laguna_(province)" title="Laguna (province)">Laguna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Quezon" title="Quezon">Quezon</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[506]</a></sup> with a separate short track in the <a href="/wiki/Bicol_Region" title="Bicol Region">Bicol Region</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[507]</a></sup> There are plans to revive <a href="/wiki/Freight_transport" title="Freight transport">freight transport</a> to reduce road congestion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[508]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[509]</a></sup> As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country had a railway footprint of only 79 kilometers, which it had plans to expand up to 244 kilometers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[510]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[511]</a></sup> Metro Manila is served by three rapid transit lines: <a href="/wiki/LRT_Line_1_(Metro_Manila)" title="LRT Line 1 (Metro Manila)">LRT Line 1</a>, <a href="/wiki/LRT_Line_2" title="LRT Line 2">LRT Line 2</a> and <a href="/wiki/MRT_Line_3_(Metro_Manila)" title="MRT Line 3 (Metro Manila)">MRT Line 3</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yellow_516-0"><a href="#cite_note-yellow-516">[512]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-provision_517-0"><a href="#cite_note-provision-517">[513]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-times_518-0"><a href="#cite_note-times-518">[514]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/PNR_Metro_Commuter_Line" title="PNR Metro Commuter Line">PNR South Commuter Line</a> transports passengers between Metro Manila and Laguna.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[515]</a></sup> Railway lines that are under construction include the 22.8-kilometer (14.2 mi) <a href="/wiki/MRT_Line_7" title="MRT Line 7">MRT Line 7</a> (2020),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[516]</a></sup> the 35-kilometer (22 mi) <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila_Subway" title="Metro Manila Subway">Metro Manila Subway</a> (2025),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[517]</a></sup> and the 109-kilometer (68 mi) PNR <a href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Commuter_Railway" title="North–South Commuter Railway">North–South Commuter Railway</a> which is divided into several phases, with partial operations to begin in 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[518]</a></sup> The civil airline industry is regulated by the <a href="/wiki/Civil_Aviation_Authority_of_the_Philippines" title="Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines">Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[519]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Philippine_Airlines" title="Philippine Airlines">Philippine Airlines</a> is Asia's oldest commercial airline still operating under its original name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PAL_524-0"><a href="#cite_note-PAL-524">[520]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[521]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cebu_Pacific" title="Cebu Pacific">Cebu Pacific</a> is the countries leading <a href="/wiki/Low-cost_carrier" title="Low-cost carrier">low-cost carrier</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OxfordBG_526-0"><a href="#cite_note-OxfordBG-526">[522]</a></sup>
</p><p>As an archipelago, inter-island travel using watercraft is often necessary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[523]</a></sup> Boats have always been important to societies in the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Isorena_528-0"><a href="#cite_note-Isorena-528">[524]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unescoboats_529-0"><a href="#cite_note-Unescoboats-529">[525]</a></sup> Most boats are <a href="/wiki/Outrigger_boat" title="Outrigger boat">double-outrigger</a> vessels, which can reach up to 30 meters (98 ft) in length, known as <i>banca</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aguilar_530-0"><a href="#cite_note-aguilar-530">[526]</a></sup>/<i>bangka</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Funtecha_531-0"><a href="#cite_note-Funtecha-531">[527]</a></sup> <i>parao</i>, prahu, or <i>balanghay</i>. A variety of boat types are used throughout the islands, such as <a href="/wiki/Dugout_canoe" title="Dugout canoe">dugouts</a> (<i>baloto</i>) and house-boats like the <i>lepa-lepa</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unescoboats_529-1"><a href="#cite_note-Unescoboats-529">[525]</a></sup> Terms such as <i>bangka</i> and <i>baroto</i> are also used as general names for a variety of boat types.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Funtecha_531-1"><a href="#cite_note-Funtecha-531">[527]</a></sup> Modern ships use plywood in place of logs and motor engines in place of sails.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aguilar_530-1"><a href="#cite_note-aguilar-530">[526]</a></sup> These ships are used both for fishing and for inter-island travel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Funtecha_531-2"><a href="#cite_note-Funtecha-531">[527]</a></sup> The principal seaports of <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Manila" title="Port of Manila">Manila</a>, <a href="/wiki/Batangas_International_Port" title="Batangas International Port">Batangas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Subic_Bay" title="Port of Subic Bay">Subic Bay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Cebu" title="Port of Cebu">Cebu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Iloilo" title="Port of Iloilo">Iloilo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Davao" title="Port of Davao">Davao</a>, Cagayan de Oro, General Santos, and <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Zamboanga" title="Port of Zamboanga">Zamboanga</a> form part of the ASEAN Transport Network.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[528]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[529]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pasig_River_Ferry" title="Pasig River Ferry">Pasig River Ferry</a> serves the cities of Manila, Makati, Mandaluyong, Pasig and Marikina in Metro Manila.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[530]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[531]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_the_Philippines" title="Water supply and sanitation in the Philippines">Water supply and sanitation in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="641" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg/220px-Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg/330px-Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg/440px-Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ambuklao_Dam" title="Ambuklao Dam">Ambuklao Dam</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bokod,_Benguet" title="Bokod, Benguet">Bokod</a>, <a href="/wiki/Benguet" title="Benguet">Benguet</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In 2015, it was reported by the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Monitoring_Programme_for_Water_Supply_and_Sanitation" title="Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation">Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation</a> that 74% of the population had access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">improved sanitation</a>, and that "good progress" had been made between 1990 and 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Organization2015_536-0"><a href="#cite_note-Organization2015-536">[532]</a></sup> As of 2016, 96% of Filipino households have an improved source of drinking water, and 92% of households had sanitary toilet facilities, although connections of these toilet facilities to appropriate sewerage systems remain largely insufficient especially in rural and urban poor communities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_46)_537-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_46)-537">[533]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Philippines" title="Culture of the Philippines">Culture of the Philippines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arts_in_the_Philippines" title="Arts in the Philippines">Arts in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg/220px-Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg/330px-Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg/440px-Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A participant of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ati-Atihan_Festival" title="Ati-Atihan Festival">Ati-Atihan Festival</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>There is significant cultural diversity across the islands, reinforced by the fragmented geography of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bankoff_538-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bankoff-538">[534]</a></sup> The cultures within Mindanao and the Sulu Archipelago developed in a particularly distinct manner, since they had very limited Spanish influence and greater influence from nearby Islamic regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[535]</a></sup> Despite this, a <a href="/wiki/Filipino_nationalism" title="Filipino nationalism">national identity</a> <a href="/wiki/National_revival" title="National revival">emerged</a> in the 19th century, the development of which is represented by <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_the_Philippines" title="National symbols of the Philippines">shared national symbols</a> and other cultural and historical touchstones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bankoff_538-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bankoff-538">[534]</a></sup>
</p><p>One of the most visible <a href="/wiki/Spanish_influence_on_Filipino_culture" title="Spanish influence on Filipino culture">Hispanic legacies</a> is the prevalence of <a href="/wiki/Cat%C3%A1logo_alfab%C3%A9tico_de_apellidos" title="Catálogo alfabético de apellidos">Spanish names and surnames</a> among Filipinos; a Spanish name and surname, however, does not necessarily denote Spanish ancestry. This peculiarity, unique among the people of Asia, came as a result of a colonial edict by Governor-General <a href="/wiki/Narciso_Claver%C3%ADa_y_Zald%C3%BAa" title="Narciso Clavería y Zaldúa">Narciso Clavería y Zaldua</a>, which ordered the systematic distribution of family names and implementation of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_naming_customs" title="Spanish naming customs">Hispanic nomenclature</a> on the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dumont_540-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dumont-540">[536]</a></sup> The names of many locations are also Spanish or stem from Spanish roots and origins.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[537]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is a substantial American influence on modern Filipino culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-3"><a href="#cite_note-Banlaoi-263">[259]</a></sup> The common use of the English language is an example of the American impact on Philippine society. It has contributed to the influence of American pop cultural trends.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542"><a href="#cite_note-542">[538]</a></sup> This affinity is seen in Filipinos' consumption of <a href="/wiki/Fast_food" title="Fast food">fast food</a> and American film and music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543"><a href="#cite_note-543">[539]</a></sup> American global fast-food chain stalwarts have entered the market, but local fast-food chains like <a href="/wiki/Goldilocks_Bakeshop" title="Goldilocks Bakeshop">Goldilocks</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[540]</a></sup> and most notably <a href="/wiki/Jollibee" title="Jollibee">Jollibee</a>, the leading fast-food chain in the country, have emerged and compete successfully against foreign chains.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jollibee2_545-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jollibee2-545">[541]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/List_of_festivals_in_the_Philippines" title="List of festivals in the Philippines">Nationwide festivals</a> include <a href="/wiki/Ati-Atihan_festival" title="Ati-Atihan festival">Ati-Atihan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dinagyang" title="Dinagyang">Dinagyang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moriones_Festival" title="Moriones Festival">Moriones</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sinulog" title="Sinulog">Sinulog</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546"><a href="#cite_note-546">[542]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[543]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[544]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Values">Values</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Filipino_values" title="Filipino values">Filipino values</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Core_Value.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1728" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Core_Value.JPG/220px-Core_Value.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Core_Value.JPG/330px-Core_Value.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Core_Value.JPG/440px-Core_Value.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Core_Value.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A statue in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iriga_City" title="Iriga City">Iriga City</a> commemorating the <i><a href="/wiki/Mano_(gesture)" title="Mano (gesture)">mano po</a></i> gesture</div></div></div>
<p>As a general description, the distinct <a href="/wiki/Value_(ethics_and_social_sciences)" title="Value (ethics and social sciences)">value system</a> of Filipinos is rooted primarily in personal alliance systems, especially those based in kinship, obligation, friendship, religion (particularly Christianity), and commercial relationships.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CAPH_549-0"><a href="#cite_note-CAPH-549">[545]</a></sup> Filipino values are, for the most part, centered around maintaining social harmony, motivated primarily by the desire to be accepted within a group. The main sanction against diverging from these values are the concepts of "<i>Hiya</i>", roughly translated as 'a sense of shame',<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a href="#cite_note-550">[546]</a></sup> and "<i>Amor propio</i>" or 'self-esteem'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Phil_551-0"><a href="#cite_note-Phil-551">[547]</a></sup> Social approval, acceptance by a group, and belonging to a group are major concerns. Caring about what others will think, say or do, are strong influences on social behavior among Filipinos.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Didache_552-0"><a href="#cite_note-Didache-552">[548]</a></sup> Other elements of the Filipino value system are optimism about the future, pessimism about present situations and events, concern and care for other people, the existence of friendship and friendliness, the habit of being hospitable, religious nature, respectfulness to self and others, respect for the female members of society, the fear of God, and abhorrence of acts of cheating and thievery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[549]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRVP2_554-0"><a href="#cite_note-CRVP2-554">[550]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_the_Philippines" title="Architecture of the Philippines">Architecture of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vigan_Calle_Crisologo_5.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Vigan_Calle_Crisologo_5.jpg/220px-Vigan_Calle_Crisologo_5.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Vigan_Calle_Crisologo_5.jpg/330px-Vigan_Calle_Crisologo_5.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Vigan_Calle_Crisologo_5.jpg/440px-Vigan_Calle_Crisologo_5.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vigan_Calle_Crisologo_5.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Colonial houses in <a href="/wiki/Vigan" title="Vigan">Vigan</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Spanish_architecture" title="Spanish architecture">Spanish architecture</a> has left an imprint in the Philippines in the way many towns were designed around a <a href="/wiki/Poblacion" title="Poblacion">central square</a> or <i>plaza mayor</i>, but many of the buildings bearing its influence were demolished during World War II.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ring_52-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ring-52">[48]</a></sup> Four Philippine <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">baroque</a> churches are included in the list of UNESCO <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a>: the <a href="/wiki/San_Agustin_Church_(Manila)" title="San Agustin Church (Manila)">San Agustín Church</a> in Manila, <a href="/wiki/Paoay_Church" title="Paoay Church">Paoay Church</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ilocos_Norte" title="Ilocos Norte">Ilocos Norte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santa_Maria_Church_(Ilocos_Sur)" title="Santa Maria Church (Ilocos Sur)">Nuestra Señora de la Asunción</a> (Santa María) Church in <a href="/wiki/Ilocos_Sur" title="Ilocos Sur">Ilocos Sur</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Miagao_Church" title="Miagao Church">Santo Tomás de Villanueva Church</a> in <a href="/wiki/Iloilo" title="Iloilo">Iloilo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unesco_555-0"><a href="#cite_note-Unesco-555">[551]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vigan" title="Vigan">Vigan</a> in Ilocos Sur is known for the many Hispanic-style houses and buildings preserved there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet145_556-0"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet145-556">[552]</a></sup>
</p><p>American rule introduced new architectural styles. This led to the construction of government buildings and <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> theaters. During the American period, some semblance of city planning using the architectural designs and master plans by <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Burnham" title="Daniel Burnham">Daniel Burnham</a> was done on the portions of the city of Manila. Part of the Burnham plan was the construction of government buildings that resembled <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_architecture" title="Ancient Greek architecture">Greek</a> or <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">Neoclassical architecture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557"><a href="#cite_note-557">[553]</a></sup> In Iloilo, structures from both the Spanish and American periods can still be seen, especially in <a href="/wiki/Calle_Real,_Iloilo" title="Calle Real, Iloilo">Calle Real</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558"><a href="#cite_note-558">[554]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (July 2020)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Certain areas of the country like <a href="/wiki/Batanes" title="Batanes">Batanes</a> have slight differences as both Spanish and Filipino ways of architecture assimilated differently because of the climate. Limestone was used as a building material, with houses being built to withstand typhoons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nccabatanes_559-0"><a href="#cite_note-nccabatanes-559">[555]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music_and_dance">Music and dance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_Philippines" title="Music of the Philippines">Music of the Philippines</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_dance" title="Philippine dance">Philippine dance</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6016" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg/220px-Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg/330px-Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg/440px-Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Cari%C3%B1osa" title="Cariñosa">Cariñosa</a>, a Hispanic era dance for traditional Filipino courtship.</div></div></div>
<p>In general, there are two types of Philippine <a href="/wiki/Folk_dance" title="Folk dance">folk dance</a>, stemming from traditional tribal influences and from Spanish influence. Spanish-influenced music are mostly <a href="/wiki/Bandurria" title="Bandurria">bandurria</a>-based bands that utilizes 14th string guitars. One example of such type is the <a href="/wiki/Cari%C3%B1osa" title="Cariñosa">Cariñosa</a>. A Hispanic Filipino dance, unofficially considered as the "National Dance of the Philippines".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-560"><a href="#cite_note-560">[556]</a></sup> Another example is the <a href="/wiki/Tinikling" title="Tinikling">Tinikling</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-561"><a href="#cite_note-561">[557]</a></sup> While native dances had become less popular over time,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Villaruz_562-0"><a href="#cite_note-Villaruz-562">[558]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 77">: 77 </span></sup> a revival of folk dances began in the 1920s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Villaruz_562-1"><a href="#cite_note-Villaruz-562">[558]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 82">: 82 </span></sup> In the modern and post-modern time periods, dances may vary from the delicate <a href="/wiki/Ballet" title="Ballet">ballet</a> up to the more street-oriented styles of <a href="/wiki/Breakdancing" title="Breakdancing">breakdancing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nccadance_563-0"><a href="#cite_note-nccadance-563">[559]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-564"><a href="#cite_note-564">[560]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Spanish era <a href="/wiki/Rondalla" title="Rondalla">Rondalya</a> music, where traditional string orchestra <a href="/wiki/Mandolin" title="Mandolin">mandolin</a> type instruments were used, was widespread.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FameNYC_565-0"><a href="#cite_note-FameNYC-565">[561]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kundiman" title="Kundiman">Kundiman</a> developed in the 1920s and 1930s<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ellingham-Mark_566-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ellingham-Mark-566">[562]</a></sup> and had a renaissance in the postwar period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-567"><a href="#cite_note-567">[563]</a></sup> The American colonial period exposed many Filipinos to <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States" title="Culture of the United States">U.S. culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States" title="Music of the United States">popular forms</a> of music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ellingham-Mark_566-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ellingham-Mark-566">[562]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">Rock music</a> was introduced to Filipinos in the 1960s and developed into Filipino rock, or "<a href="/wiki/Pinoy_rock" title="Pinoy rock">Pinoy rock</a>", a term encompassing diverse styles such as <a href="/wiki/Pop_rock" title="Pop rock">pop rock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alternative_rock" title="Alternative rock">alternative rock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Punk_rock" title="Punk rock">punk</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_wave_music" title="New wave music">new wave</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ska" title="Ska">ska</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Reggae" title="Reggae">reggae</a>. Martial law in the 1970s produced several <a href="/wiki/Philippine_folk_music" title="Philippine folk music">Filipino folk rock</a> bands and artists who were at the forefront of political demonstrations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-568"><a href="#cite_note-568">[564]</a></sup> The 1970s also saw the birth of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manila_Sound" title="Manila Sound">Manila Sound</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-569"><a href="#cite_note-569">[565]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Original_Pilipino_Music" title="Original Pilipino Music">Original Pilipino Music</a> (OPM).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-570"><a href="#cite_note-570">[566]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filipino_hip-hop" title="Filipino hip-hop">Filipino hip-hop</a> traces its origins back to 1979, entering the mainstream in 1990.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[567]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-572"><a href="#cite_note-572">[568]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Karaoke" title="Karaoke">Karaoke</a> is a popular activity in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573"><a href="#cite_note-573">[569]</a></sup> From 2010 to 2020, Philippine pop music or <a href="/wiki/Pinoy_pop" title="Pinoy pop">P-pop</a> went through a metamorphosis in its increased quality, budget, investment, and variety, matching the country's rapid economic growth and an accompanying social and cultural resurgence of its Asian identity. This was heard by heavy influence from <a href="/wiki/K-pop" title="K-pop">K-pop</a> and <a href="/wiki/J-pop" title="J-pop">J-pop</a>, growth in Asian style ballads, idol groups, and <a href="/wiki/Electronic_dance_music" title="Electronic dance music">electronic dance music</a>, and less reliance on Western genres, mirroring the <a href="/wiki/Korean_wave" title="Korean wave">Korean wave</a> and similar Japanese wave popularity among millennial Filipinos and mainstream culture.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Locally produced spoken dramas became established in the late 1870s. Around the same time, Spanish influence led to the introduction of <i><a href="/wiki/Zarzuela" title="Zarzuela">zarzuela</a></i> plays which integrated musical pieces,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Liu_574-0"><a href="#cite_note-Liu-574">[570]</a></sup> and of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Comedia_(Spanish_play)" title="Comedia (Spanish play)">comedia</a></i> plays which included more significant dance elements. Such performances became popular throughout the country<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Villaruz_562-2"><a href="#cite_note-Villaruz-562">[558]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 69–70">: 69–70 </span></sup> and were written in a number of local languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Liu_574-1"><a href="#cite_note-Liu-574">[570]</a></sup> American influence led to the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Vaudeville" title="Vaudeville">vaudeville</a> and ballet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Villaruz_562-3"><a href="#cite_note-Villaruz-562">[558]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 69–70">: 69–70 </span></sup> During the 20th century the <a href="/wiki/Realism_(theatre)" title="Realism (theatre)">realism</a> genre became more dominant, with performances written to focus on contemporary political and societal issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Liu_574-2"><a href="#cite_note-Liu-574">[570]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Philippine_literature" title="Philippine literature">Philippine literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jose_Rizal_full.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1358" data-file-width="955" decoding="async" height="242" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Jose_Rizal_full.jpg/170px-Jose_Rizal_full.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Jose_Rizal_full.jpg/255px-Jose_Rizal_full.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Jose_Rizal_full.jpg/340px-Jose_Rizal_full.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jose_Rizal_full.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Rizal" title="José Rizal">José Rizal</a> is a pioneer of <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolution" title="Philippine Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a> through his literary works.</div></div></div>
<p>Philippine literature comprises works usually written in Filipino, Spanish, or English. Some of the most known were created from the 17th to 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-575"><a href="#cite_note-575">[571]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Ibong_Adarna" title="Ibong Adarna">Ibong Adarna</a></i>, for example, is a famous epic about an eponymous magical bird allegedly written by José de la Cruz or "<a href="/wiki/Huseng_Sisiw" title="Huseng Sisiw">Huseng Sisiw</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-576"><a href="#cite_note-576">[572]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Balagtas" title="Francisco Balagtas">Francisco Balagtas</a>, the poet and playwright who wrote <i><a href="/wiki/Florante_at_Laura" title="Florante at Laura">Florante at Laura</a></i>, is recognized as a preeminent writer in the Tagalog language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-577"><a href="#cite_note-577">[573]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Rizal" title="José Rizal">José Rizal</a> wrote the novels <i><a href="/wiki/Noli_Me_T%C3%A1ngere_(novel)" title="Noli Me Tángere (novel)">Noli Me Tángere</a></i> (<i>Touch Me Not</i>) and <i><a href="/wiki/El_filibusterismo" title="El filibusterismo">El filibusterismo</a></i> (<i>The Filibustering</i>, also known as <i>The Reign of Greed</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-578"><a href="#cite_note-578">[574]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Philippine_mythology" title="Philippine mythology">Philippine mythology</a> has been handed down primarily through the traditional <a href="/wiki/Philippine_folk_literature" title="Philippine folk literature">oral folk literature</a> of the Filipino people. Some popular figures from Philippine mythologies are <a href="/wiki/Maria_Makiling" title="Maria Makiling">Maria Makiling</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biag_ni_Lam-Ang" title="Biag ni Lam-Ang">Lam-Ang</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sarimanok" title="Sarimanok">Sarimanok</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lopez_579-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lopez-579">[575]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_Philippines" title="Cinema of the Philippines">Cinema of the Philippines</a></div>
<p>Philippine cinema began at the end of the 19th century<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-580"><a href="#cite_note-580">[576]</a></sup> and made up around 20% of the domestic market during the second half of the 20th century. During the 21st century however, the industry has struggled to compete with larger budget foreign films.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-581"><a href="#cite_note-581">[577]</a></sup> Critically acclaimed Philippines films include <i><a href="/wiki/Himala" title="Himala">Himala</a></i> (<i>Miracle</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582"><a href="#cite_note-582">[578]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583"><a href="#cite_note-583">[579]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-584"><a href="#cite_note-584">[580]</a></sup> Moving pictures were first shown in the Philippines on January 1, 1897.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-585"><a href="#cite_note-585">[581]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-586"><a href="#cite_note-586">[582]</a></sup> Films were all in Spanish since Philippine cinema was first introduced during the final years of the Spanish era of the country. Antonio Ramos was the first known movie producer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-587"><a href="#cite_note-587">[583]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-588"><a href="#cite_note-588">[584]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Nepomuceno" title="José Nepomuceno">Jose Nepomuceno</a> was dubbed as the "Father of Philippine Movies".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-589"><a href="#cite_note-589">[585]</a></sup> His work marked the start of the local production of movies. Production companies remained small during the era of <a href="/wiki/Silent_film" title="Silent film">silent film</a>, but 1933 saw the emergence of sound films and the arrival of the first significant production company. The postwar 1940s and the 1950s are regarded as a high point for Philippine cinema.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.com_113-1"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-113">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>The growing dominance of <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States" title="Cinema of the United States">Hollywood</a> films and the cost of production has severely reduced local filmmaking.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bleak_590-0"><a href="#cite_note-bleak-590">[586]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dying_591-0"><a href="#cite_note-dying-591">[587]</a></sup> Nonetheless, some local films continue to find success.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TadhanaABSCBN20150220_592-0"><a href="#cite_note-TadhanaABSCBN20150220-592">[588]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TadhanaABSCBN20150303_593-0"><a href="#cite_note-TadhanaABSCBN20150303-593">[589]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mass_media">Mass media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_in_the_Philippines" title="Media in the Philippines">Media in the Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Television_in_the_Philippines" title="Television in the Philippines">Television in the Philippines</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Radio_in_the_Philippines" title="Radio in the Philippines">Radio in the Philippines</a></div>
<p>Philippine media uses mainly Filipino and English, though <a href="/wiki/Broadcasting" title="Broadcasting">broadcasting</a> has shifted to Filipino.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BrownGanguly2003_396-1"><a href="#cite_note-BrownGanguly2003-396">[392]</a></sup> There are large numbers of both <a href="/wiki/List_of_radio_stations_in_the_Philippines" title="List of radio stations in the Philippines">radio stations</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_the_Philippines" title="List of newspapers in the Philippines">newspapers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Pilipinas_594-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Pilipinas-594">[590]</a></sup> The top three newspapers by nationwide readership as well as credibility<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-595"><a href="#cite_note-595">[591]</a></sup> are the <i><a href="/wiki/Philippine_Daily_Inquirer" title="Philippine Daily Inquirer">Philippine Daily Inquirer</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Manila_Bulletin" title="Manila Bulletin">Manila Bulletin</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Philippine_Star" title="The Philippine Star">The Philippine Star</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-596"><a href="#cite_note-596">[592]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-597"><a href="#cite_note-597">[593]</a></sup> While <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a> is protected by the constitution, the country is very dangerous for journalists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Pilipinas_594-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Pilipinas-594">[590]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-598"><a href="#cite_note-598">[594]</a></sup>
</p><p>The dominant television networks were <a href="/wiki/ABS-CBN" title="ABS-CBN">ABS-CBN</a> and <a href="/wiki/GMA_Network" title="GMA Network">GMA</a>, both being <a href="/wiki/Free-to-air" title="Free-to-air">free-to-air</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Pilipinas_594-2"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Pilipinas-594">[590]</a></sup> ABS-CBN, at the time the largest network<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gutierrez_599-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gutierrez-599">[595]</a></sup> was shut down following a cease and desist order issued by the National Telecommunications Commission on May 5, 2020, a day after the <a href="/wiki/ABS-CBN_franchise_renewal_controversy" title="ABS-CBN franchise renewal controversy">expiration of the network's franchise</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-600"><a href="#cite_note-600">[596]</a></sup> Prior to this move, Duterte accused ABS-CBN of being biased against his administration and vowed to block the renewal of their franchise. Critics of the Duterte administration, human rights groups, and media unions said the shutdown of ABS-CBN was an attack on press freedom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gutierrez_599-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gutierrez-599">[595]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-601"><a href="#cite_note-601">[597]</a></sup> On July 10, 2020, the House of Representatives declined a renewal of ABS-CBN's TV and radio franchise, with a vote of 70–11.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gutierrez_599-2"><a href="#cite_note-Gutierrez-599">[595]</a></sup>
</p><p>TV, the Internet,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-602"><a href="#cite_note-602">[598]</a></sup> and social media remain the top source of news and information for the majority of Filipinos as newspaper readership continues to decline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-603"><a href="#cite_note-603">[599]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-604"><a href="#cite_note-604">[600]</a></sup> English broadsheets are popular among executives, professionals and students.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ThompsonRogerM2003_605-0"><a href="#cite_note-ThompsonRogerM2003-605">[601]</a></sup> Cheaper Tagalog tabloids, which feature crime, sex, gossips and gore, saw a rise in the 1990s, and tend to be popular among the masses, particularly in Manila.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ThompsonRogerM2003_605-1"><a href="#cite_note-ThompsonRogerM2003-605">[601]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-606"><a href="#cite_note-606">[602]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-607"><a href="#cite_note-607">[603]</a></sup>
</p><p>Estimates for Internet penetration in the Philippines vary widely ranging from a low of 2.5 million to a high of 24 million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ntc2_608-0"><a href="#cite_note-ntc2-608">[604]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-609"><a href="#cite_note-609">[605]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Social_media_use_in_the_Philippines" title="Social media use in the Philippines">Social networking</a> and watching videos are among the most frequent Internet activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Capital_610-0"><a href="#cite_note-Capital-610">[606]</a></sup> The Philippine population is the world's top internet user.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-611"><a href="#cite_note-611">[607]</a></sup> The Philippines was ranked 51st in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021, it has increased its ranking considerably since 2014, where it was ranked 100th.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-612"><a href="#cite_note-612">[608]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-613"><a href="#cite_note-613">[609]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-614"><a href="#cite_note-614">[610]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-615"><a href="#cite_note-615">[611]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Filipino_cuisine" title="Filipino cuisine">Filipino cuisine</a></div>
<p>Regional variations exist throughout the islands, for example rice is a standard starch in Luzon while <a href="/wiki/Cassava" title="Cassava">cassava</a> is more common in Mindanao.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zibart_616-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zibart-616">[612]</a></sup> Filipino taste buds tend to favor robust flavors,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-617"><a href="#cite_note-617">[613]</a></sup> but the cuisine is not as spicy as those of its neighbors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zialcita_618-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zialcita-618">[614]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (July 2020)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup> Unlike many Asians, most Filipinos do not eat with <a href="/wiki/Chopsticks" title="Chopsticks">chopsticks</a>; they use Western cutlery.
