Since rice is the primary <a href="/wiki/Staple_food" title="Staple food">staple food</a> and stews and broths are very common in Filipino cuisine, the main of utensils are spoons and forks, not knife and fork.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet48_619-0"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet48-619">[615]</a></sup>
</p><p>The traditional way of eating with the hands known as <i>kamayan</i> (using the hand for bringing food to the mouth)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-620"><a href="#cite_note-620">[616]</a></sup> was previously more often seen in the less urbanized areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zibart_616-1"><a href="#cite_note-Zibart-616">[612]</a></sup> Introduction of Filipino food to people of other nationalities, as well as to Filipino urbanites,  has popularized <i>kamayan</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-621"><a href="#cite_note-621">[617]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-622"><a href="#cite_note-622">[618]</a></sup> This recent trend also sometimes incorporates the "boodle fight" concept (as popularized and coined by the Philippine Army), wherein banana leaves are used as giant plates on top of which rice portions and Filipino viands are placed all together for a filial, friendly or communal <i>kamayan</i> feasting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-623"><a href="#cite_note-623">[619]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_the_Philippines" title="Sports in the Philippines">Sports in the Philippines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Traditional_games_in_the_Philippines" title="Traditional games in the Philippines">Traditional games in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gilas_Cadets_2015_SEA_Games.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4016" data-file-width="6016" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Gilas_Cadets_2015_SEA_Games.jpg/220px-Gilas_Cadets_2015_SEA_Games.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Gilas_Cadets_2015_SEA_Games.jpg/330px-Gilas_Cadets_2015_SEA_Games.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Gilas_Cadets_2015_SEA_Games.jpg/440px-Gilas_Cadets_2015_SEA_Games.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gilas_Cadets_2015_SEA_Games.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Philippines_men%27s_national_basketball_team" title="Philippines men's national basketball team">Philippines men's national basketball team</a> celebrating the <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_2015_Southeast_Asian_Games" title="Basketball at the 2015 Southeast Asian Games">2015 Southeast Asian Games</a> championship.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Basketball_in_the_Philippines" title="Basketball in the Philippines">Basketball</a> is played at both amateur and professional levels and is considered to be the most popular sport in the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-624"><a href="#cite_note-624">[620]</a></sup> In 2010, <a href="/wiki/Manny_Pacquiao" title="Manny Pacquiao">Manny Pacquiao</a> was named "<a href="/wiki/Sugar_Ray_Robinson_Award#2000s" title="Sugar Ray Robinson Award">Fighter of the Decade</a>" for the 2000s by the <a href="/wiki/Boxing_Writers_Association_of_America" title="Boxing Writers Association of America">Boxing Writers Association of America</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pacquiao_named_Fighter_of_the_Decade_625-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pacquiao_named_Fighter_of_the_Decade-625">[621]</a></sup> The national <a href="/wiki/Filipino_martial_arts" title="Filipino martial arts">martial art</a> and sport of the country is <a href="/wiki/Arnis" title="Arnis">Arnis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-626"><a href="#cite_note-626">[622]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-627"><a href="#cite_note-627">[623]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cockfight" title="Cockfight">Sabong</a> or cockfighting is another popular entertainment especially among Filipino men and was documented by Magellan's voyage as a pastime in the kingdom of Taytay.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-628"><a href="#cite_note-628">[624]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Philippines_national_football_team" title="Philippines national football team">men's national football team</a> has participated in one <a href="/wiki/2019_AFC_Asian_Cup" title="2019 AFC Asian Cup">Asian Cup</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-629"><a href="#cite_note-629">[625]</a></sup> In January 2022, the <a href="/wiki/Philippines_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Philippines women's national football team">women's national football team</a> qualified in their first <a href="/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup" title="FIFA Women's World Cup">FIFA Women's World Cup</a>—the <a href="/wiki/2023_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup" title="2023 FIFA Women's World Cup">2023 FIFA Women's World Cup</a>—upon defeating <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Chinese Taipei women's national football team">Chinese Taipei</a> 4–3 in a penalty shootout after finishing 1–1 in extra time.
</p><p>Beginning in <a href="/wiki/Philippines_at_the_1924_Summer_Olympics" title="Philippines at the 1924 Summer Olympics">1924</a>, the Philippines has competed in every <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a>, except when they sat out during the <a href="/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics_boycott" title="1980 Summer Olympics boycott">American-led boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-630"><a href="#cite_note-630">[626]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-631"><a href="#cite_note-631">[627]</a></sup> The Philippines is the first <a href="/wiki/Tropical_nations_at_the_Winter_Olympics" title="Tropical nations at the Winter Olympics">tropical nation</a> to compete at the <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">Winter Olympic Games</a> <a href="/wiki/Philippines_at_the_1972_Winter_Olympics" title="Philippines at the 1972 Winter Olympics">debuting in the 1972</a> Olympics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-632"><a href="#cite_note-632">[628]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-633"><a href="#cite_note-633">[629]</a></sup> In 2021, the country tallied its first ever Olympic gold medal via <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">weightlifter</a> <a href="/wiki/Hidilyn_Diaz" title="Hidilyn Diaz">Hidilyn Diaz</a>'s victory at the <a href="/wiki/2020_Summer_Olympics" title="2020 Summer Olympics">Tokyo Olympics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-634"><a href="#cite_note-634">[630]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-a-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-a_4-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> is designated as the nation's capital, the <a href="/wiki/Seat_of_government" title="Seat of government">seat of government</a> is the <i>National Capital Region</i>, commonly known as "<a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a>", of which the city of Manila is a part.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Many national government institutions are located on various parts of Metro Manila, aside from <a href="/wiki/Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace" title="Malacañang Palace">Malacañang Palace</a> and other institutions/agencies that are located within the Manila capital city.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-b-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-b_6-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As per the 1987 Constitution: "Spanish and Arabic shall be promoted on a voluntary and optional basis."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-c-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-c_16-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Since March 10, 1945<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[13]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-d-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-d_18-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In the recognized regional <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_Philippines" title="Languages of the Philippines">languages of the Philippines</a>:
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r998391716">.mw-parser-output .div-col{margin-top:0.3em;column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .div-col-small{font-size:90%}.mw-parser-output .div-col-rules{column-rule:1px solid #aaa}.mw-parser-output .div-col dl,.mw-parser-output .div-col ol,.mw-parser-output .div-col ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .div-col li,.mw-parser-output .div-col dd{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 30em;">
<ul><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aklan_language" title="Aklan language">Aklan</a>: <i lang="akl">Republika it Pilipinas</i></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bikol_language" title="Bikol language">Bikol</a>: <i lang="bik">Republika kan Filipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Cebuano_language" title="Cebuano language">Cebuano</a>: <i lang="ceb">Republika sa Pilipinas</i></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chavacano_language" title="Chavacano language">Chavacano</a>: <i lang="cbk">República de Filipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hiligaynon_language" title="Hiligaynon language">Hiligaynon</a>: <i lang="hil">Republika sang Filipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ibanag_language" title="Ibanag language">Ibanag</a>: <i lang="ibg">Republika nat Filipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ilocano_language" title="Ilocano language">Ilocano</a>: <i lang="ilo">Republika ti Filipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ivatan_language" title="Ivatan language">Ivatan</a>: <i lang="ivv">Republika nu Filipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kapampangan_language" title="Kapampangan language">Kapampangan</a>: <i lang="pam">Republika ning Filipinas</i></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kinaray-a_language" title="Kinaray-a language">Kinaray-a</a>: <i lang="krj">Republika kang Pilipinas</i></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maguindanaon_language" title="Maguindanaon language">Maguindanaon</a>: <i lang="mdh">Republika nu Pilipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Maranao_language" title="Maranao language">Maranao</a>: <i lang="mrw">Republika a Pilipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pangasinan_language" title="Pangasinan language">Pangasinan</a>: <i lang="pag">Republika na Filipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sambal_language" title="Sambal language">Sambal</a>: <i lang="xsb">Republika nin Pilipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Surigaonon_language" title="Surigaonon language">Surigaonon</a>: <i lang="sgd">Republika nan Pilipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">Tagalog</a>: <i lang="tl">Republika ng Pilipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tausug_language" title="Tausug language">Tausug</a>: <i lang="tsg">Republika sin Pilipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Waray_language" title="Waray language">Waray</a>: <i lang="war">Republika han Pilipinas</i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Yakan_language" title="Yakan language">Yakan</a>: <i lang="yka">Republika si Pilipinas</i></li></ul>
</div>
<p>In the recognized optional languages of the Philippines:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 30em;">

</div></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Constantino1975-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Constantino1975_25-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFConstantino1975">Constantino, R (1975). <i>The Philippines: a Past Revisited</i>. <li id="cite_note-Lipson2014-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lipson2014_37-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" <li id="cite_note-Larena-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Larena_38-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Larena_38-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLarenaSanchez-QuintoSjödinMcKenna2021">Larena, <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8020671" rel="nofollow">"Multiple migrations to the Philippines during the last 50,000 years"</a>. <i>Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences</i>. <b>118</b> (13): e2026132118. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1073%2Fpnas.2026132118" rel="nofollow">10.1073/pnas.2026132118</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN <li id="cite_note-Ring-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Ring_52-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Ring_52-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFRing,_TrudyRobert_M._SalkinSharon_La_Boda1996">Ring, Trudy; Robert M. Salkin &amp; Sharon La Boda (1996). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=vWLRxJEU49EC&amp;pg=PA565" rel="nofollow"><i>International Dictionary of Historic Places: Asia and Oceania</i></a>. Taylor &amp; Francis. pp. 565–569. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-884964-04-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-884964-04-6"><bdi>978-1-884964-04-6</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">January 7,</span> 2010</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=International+Dictionary+of+Historic+Places%3A+Asia+and+Oceania&amp;rft.pages=565-569&amp;rft.pub=Taylor+%26+Francis&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-884964-04-6&amp;rft.au=Ring%2C+Trudy&amp;rft.au=Robert+M.+Salkin&amp;rft.au=Sharon+La+Boda&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DvWLRxJEU49EC%26pg%3DPA565&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-53">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/historical-atlas-of-the-republic/page/n65/mode/2up" rel="nofollow"><i>Historical Atlas of the Republic</i></a>. The Presidential Communications Development and Strategic Planning Office. 2016. p. 64. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-971-95551-6-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-971-95551-6-2"><bdi>978-971-95551-6-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Historical+Atlas+of+the+Republic&amp;rft.pages=64&amp;rft.pub=The+Presidential+Communications+Development+and+Strategic+Planning+Office&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-971-95551-6-2&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fhistorical-atlas-of-the-republic%2Fpage%2Fn65%2Fmode%2F2up&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Carley2013-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Carley2013_54-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCarley2013">Carley, Michael (November 4, 2013) [2001]. <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ycT9AQAAQBAJ&amp;q=Barangay+city-states&amp;pg=PA108" rel="nofollow">"7"</a>. <i>Urban Development and Civil Society: The Role of Communities in Sustainable Cities</i>. Routledge. p. 108. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781134200504" title="Special:BookSources/9781134200504"><bdi>9781134200504</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">September 11,</span> 2020</span>. <q>Each boat carried a large family group, and the master of the boat retained power as leader, or datu, of the village established by his family. This form of village social organization can be found as early as the 13th century in Panay, Bohol, Cebu, Samar and Leyte in the Visayas, and in Batangas, Pampanga and Tondo in Luzon. Evidence suggests a considerable degree of independence as small city-states with their heads known as datu, rajah or sultan.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=7&amp;rft.btitle=Urban+Development+and+Civil+Society%3A+The+Role+of+Communities+in+Sustainable+Cities&amp;rft.pages=108&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2013-11-04&amp;rft.isbn=9781134200504&amp;rft.aulast=Carley&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DycT9AQAAQBAJ%26q%3DBarangay%2Bcity-states%26pg%3DPA108&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-55">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFTan2008">Tan, Samuel K. (2008). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=pw5FWmdNmj8C&amp;pg=PA37" rel="nofollow"><i>A History of the Philippines</i></a>. UP Press. p. 37. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-971-542-568-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-971-542-568-1"><bdi>978-971-542-568-1</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">August 10,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+the+Philippines&amp;rft.pages=37&amp;rft.pub=UP+Press&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-971-542-568-1&amp;rft.aulast=Tan&amp;rft.aufirst=Samuel+K.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dpw5FWmdNmj8C%26pg%3DPA37&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-56"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-56">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation thesis cs1" id="CITEREFReyegMarsh2011">Reyeg, Fernardo; Marsh, Ned (December 2011). <a class="external text" href="https://apps.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a556504.pdf" rel="nofollow">"2"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>The Filipino Way of War: Irregular Warfare Through The Centuries</i> (Post Graduate). Naval Postgraduate School Monterey, California. p. 21. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210415183151/https://apps.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a556504.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on April 15, 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">February 15,</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Adissertation&amp;rft.title=The+Filipino+Way+of+War%3A+Irregular+Warfare+Through+The+Centuries&amp;rft.inst=Naval+Postgraduate+School+Monterey%2C+California&amp;rft.date=2011-12&amp;rft.aulast=Reyeg&amp;rft.aufirst=Fernardo&amp;rft.au=Marsh%2C+Ned&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapps.dtic.mil%2Fdtic%2Ftr%2Ffulltext%2Fu2%2Fa556504.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-57"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-57">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFNewson2009">Newson, Linda (2009) [2009]. "2". <a class="external text" href="https://www.universitypressscholarship.com/view/10.21313/hawaii/9780824832728.001.0001/upso-9780824832728" rel="nofollow"><i>Conquest and Pestilence in the Early Spanish Philippines</i></a>. University of Hawaii Press. p. 18. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.21313%2Fhawaii%2F9780824832728.001.0001" rel="nofollow">10.21313/hawaii/9780824832728.001.0001</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780824832728" title="Special:BookSources/9780824832728"><bdi>9780824832728</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">September 11,</span> 2020</span>. <q>Given the significance of the size and distribution of the population to the spread of diseases and their ability to become endemic, it is worth commenting briefly on the physical and human geography of the Philippines. The hot and humid tropical climate would have generally favored the propagation of many diseases, especially water-borne infections, though there might be regional or seasonal variations in climate that might affect the incidence of some diseases. In general, however, the fact that the Philippines comprise some seven thousand islands, some of which are uninhabited even today, would have discouraged the spread of infections, as would the low population density.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=2&amp;rft.btitle=Conquest+and+Pestilence+in+the+Early+Spanish+Philippines&amp;rft.pages=18&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Hawaii+Press&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.21313%2Fhawaii%2F9780824832728.001.0001&amp;rft.isbn=9780824832728&amp;rft.aulast=Newson&amp;rft.aufirst=Linda&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.universitypressscholarship.com%2Fview%2F10.21313%2Fhawaii%2F9780824832728.001.0001%2Fupso-9780824832728&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBankoff2007">Bankoff, Greg (2007). "Storms of history". <a class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1163/j.ctt1w76vd0.9" rel="nofollow"><i>A World of Water</i></a>. Brill. pp. 153–184. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/10.1163/j.ctt1w76vd0.9" rel="nofollow">10.1163/j.ctt1w76vd0.9</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Storms+of+history&amp;rft.btitle=A+World+of+Water&amp;rft.pages=153-184&amp;rft.pub=Brill&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F10.1163%2Fj.ctt1w76vd0.9%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft.aulast=Bankoff&amp;rft.aufirst=Greg&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F10.1163%2Fj.ctt1w76vd0.9&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-etymology-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-etymology_59-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFZaide,_Gregorio_F.Sonia_M._Zaide2004">Zaide, Gregorio F.; Sonia M. <li id="cite_note-Basques-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Basques_61-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Basques_61-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFde_Borja2005">de Borja, Marciano R. <li id="cite_note-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-62">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source-2" id="CITEREFFernando_A._Santiago_Jr.2006">Fernando A. Santiago Jr. (2006). <a class="external text" href="https://ejournals.ph/article.php?id=7887" rel="nofollow">"Isang Maikling Kasaysayan ng Pandacan, Maynila 1589–1898"</a>. <i>Malay</i> (in Filipino). <b>19</b> (2): 70–87<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 18,</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Malay&amp;rft.atitle=Isang+Maikling+Kasaysayan+ng+Pandacan%2C+Maynila+1589%E2%80%931898&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=70-87&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.au=Fernando+A.+Santiago+Jr.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fejournals.ph%2Farticle.php%3Fid%3D7887&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-63">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFManuel_L._Quezon_III2017">Manuel L. Quezon III (June 12, 2017). <a class="external text" href="http://www.spot.ph/newsfeatures/the-latest-news-features/70433/philippine-map-palau-a1507-20170612-lfrm3" rel="nofollow">"The Philippines Isn't What It Used to Be"</a>. <i>SPOT.PH</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">October 24,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=SPOT.PH&amp;rft.atitle=The+Philippines+Isn%27t+What+It+Used+to+Be&amp;rft.date=2017-06-12&amp;rft.au=Manuel+L.+Quezon+III&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.spot.ph%2Fnewsfeatures%2Fthe-latest-news-features%2F70433%2Fphilippine-map-palau-a1507-20170612-lfrm3&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Andrade-64"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Andrade_64-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAndrade2005"><a href="/wiki/Tonio_Andrade" title="Tonio Andrade">Andrade, Tonio</a> (2005). <a class="external text" href="http://www.gutenberg-e.org/andrade/andrade04.html" rel="nofollow">"La Isla Hermosa: The Rise of the Spanish Colony in Northern Taiwan"</a>. <a class="external text" href="http://www.gutenberg-e.org/andrade/" rel="nofollow"><i>How Taiwan Became Chinese: Dutch, Spanish and Han colonialization in the Seventeenth Century</i></a>. Columbia University Press.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=La+Isla+Hermosa%3A+The+Rise+of+the+Spanish+Colony+in+Northern+Taiwan&amp;rft.btitle=How+Taiwan+Became+Chinese%3A+Dutch%2C+Spanish+and+Han+colonialization+in+the+Seventeenth+Century&amp;rft.pub=Columbia+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.aulast=Andrade&amp;rft.aufirst=Tonio&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gutenberg-e.org%2Fandrade%2Fandrade04.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-65"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-65">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGuillermo2012">Guillermo, Artemio (2012) [2012]. <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=wmgX9M_yETIC&amp;q=divide+and+conquer+philippines&amp;pg=PA374" rel="nofollow"><i>Historical Dictionary of the Philippines</i></a>. The Scarecrow Press Inc. p. 374. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780810875111" title="Special:BookSources/9780810875111"><bdi>9780810875111</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">September 11,</span> 2020</span>. <q>To pursue their mission of conquest, the Spaniards dealt individually with each settlement or village and with each province or island until the entire Philippine archipelago was brought under imperial control. They saw to it that the people remained divided or compartmentalized and with the minimum of contact or communication. The Spaniards adopted the policy of divide et impera (divide and conquer).</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Historical+Dictionary+of+the+Philippines&amp;rft.pages=374&amp;rft.pub=The+Scarecrow+Press+Inc.&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=9780810875111&amp;rft.aulast=Guillermo&amp;rft.aufirst=Artemio&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DwmgX9M_yETIC%26q%3Ddivide%2Band%2Bconquer%2Bphilippines%26pg%3DPA374&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-auto5-66"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-auto5_66-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLlobet2015">Llobet, Ruth de (June 23, 2015). <a class="external text" href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-southeast-asian-studies/article/philippines-a-mountain-of-difference-the-lumad-in-early-colonial-mindanao-by-oona-paredes-ithaca-southeast-asia-program-publications-cornell-university-2013-pp-195-maps-appendices-notes-bibliography-index/10F3EEAA42554FF4996D35ADA368B7F5" rel="nofollow">"The Philippines. <li id="cite_note-Ooi2004-75"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Ooi2004_75-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Ooi2004_75-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Ooi2004_75-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFOoi2004">Ooi, Keat Gin (2004). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QKgraWbb7yoC&amp;pg=PA1077" rel="nofollow"><i>Southeast Asia: A Historical Encyclopedia, from Angkor Wat to East Timor</i></a>. ABC-CLIO. p. 1077. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-57607-770-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-57607-770-2"><bdi>978-1-57607-770-2</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">January 29,</span> 2021</span>. <q>Because local resources did not yield enough money to maintain the colonial administration, the government was constantly running a deficit and had to be supported with an annual subsidy from the Spanish government in Mexico, the situado.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Southeast+Asia%3A+A+Historical+Encyclopedia%2C+from+Angkor+Wat+to+East+Timor&amp;rft.pages=1077&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-57607-770-2&amp;rft.aulast=Ooi&amp;rft.aufirst=Keat+Gin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQKgraWbb7yoC%26pg%3DPA1077&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-UnrulyMexicans-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-UnrulyMexicans_78-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-UnrulyMexicans_78-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-UnrulyMexicans_78-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMehl2016">Mehl, Eva Maria (2016). "Chapter 6 – Unruly Mexicans in Manila". <a class="external text" href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/forced-migration-in-the-spanish-pacific-world/unruly-mexicans-in-manila/EF2599210A0715A5A91B23BB9D84B96C" rel="nofollow"><i>Forced Migration in the Spanish Pacific World From Mexico to the Philippines, 1765–1811</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FCBO9781316480120.007" rel="nofollow">10.1017/CBO9781316480120.007</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781316480120" title="Special:BookSources/9781316480120"><bdi>9781316480120</bdi></a>. <q>In Governor Anda y Salazar's opinion, an important part of the problem of vagrancy was the fact that Mexicans and Spanish disbanded after finishing their military or prison terms "all over the islands, even the most distant, looking for subsistence.~CSIC riel 208 leg.14</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Chapter+6+%E2%80%93+Unruly+Mexicans+in+Manila&amp;rft.btitle=Forced+Migration+in+the+Spanish+Pacific+World+From+Mexico+to+the+Philippines%2C+1765%E2%80%931811&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FCBO9781316480120.007&amp;rft.isbn=9781316480120&amp;rft.aulast=Mehl&amp;rft.aufirst=Eva+Maria&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cambridge.org%2Fcore%2Fbooks%2Fforced-migration-in-the-spanish-pacific-world%2Funruly-mexicans-in-manila%2FEF2599210A0715A5A91B23BB9D84B96C&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-79">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Garcıa de los Arcos, "Grupos etnicos", 65–66 <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFGarcia_de_los_Arcos1999">Garcia de los Arcos, Maria Fernanda (1999). <a class="external text" href="https://www.persee.fr/doc/arch_0044-8613_1999_num_57_2_3515" rel="nofollow">"Grupos éthnicos y Clases sociales en las Filipinas de Finales del Siglo XVIII"</a>. <i>Archipel</i>. <b>57</b> (2): 55–71. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.3406%2Farch.1999.3515" rel="nofollow">10.3406/arch.1999.3515</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">August 19,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Archipel&amp;rft.atitle=Grupos+%C3%A9thnicos+y+Clases+sociales+en+las+Filipinas+de+Finales+del+Siglo+XVIII&amp;rft.volume=57&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=55-71&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.3406%2Farch.1999.3515&amp;rft.aulast=Garcia+de+los+Arcos&amp;rft.aufirst=Maria+Fernanda&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.persee.fr%2Fdoc%2Farch_0044-8613_1999_num_57_2_3515&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-80"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-80">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMehl2016">Mehl, Eva Maria (2016). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=h1Y2DAAAQBAJ&amp;q=CSIC+ser.+Consultas+riel+301+leg.8&amp;pg=PA256" rel="nofollow">"Chapter 1 – Intertwined Histories in the Pacific"</a>. <i>Forced Migration in the Spanish Pacific World From Mexico to the Philippines, 1765–1811</i>. Cambridge University Press. p. 246. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FCBO9781316480120.007" rel="nofollow">10.1017/CBO9781316480120.007</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781316480120" title="Special:BookSources/9781316480120"><bdi>9781316480120</bdi></a>. <q>The military organization of Manila might have depended to some degree on non-European groups, but colonial authorities measured a successful imperial policy of defense on the amount of European and American recruits that could be accounted for in the military forces.~CSIC ser. Consultas riel 301 leg.8 (1794)</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Chapter+1+%E2%80%93+Intertwined+Histories+in+the+Pacific&amp;rft.btitle=Forced+Migration+in+the+Spanish+Pacific+World+From+Mexico+to+the+Philippines%2C+1765%E2%80%931811&amp;rft.pages=246&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FCBO9781316480120.007&amp;rft.isbn=9781316480120&amp;rft.aulast=Mehl&amp;rft.aufirst=Eva+Maria&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dh1Y2DAAAQBAJ%26q%3DCSIC%2Bser.%2BConsultas%2Briel%2B301%2Bleg.8%26pg%3DPA256&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-ReferenceC-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ReferenceC_81-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://filipinokastila.tripod.com/FilMex.html" rel="nofollow">"Filipino-Mexican-Central-and-South American Connection, Tales of Two Sisters: Manila and Mexico"</a>. June 21, 1997<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">January 1,</span> 2021</span>. <q>Tomás de Comyn, general manager of the Compañia Real de Filipinas, in 1810 estimated that out of a total population of 2,515,406, "the European Spaniards, and Spanish creoles and mestizos do not exceed 4,000 persons of both sexes and all ages, and the distinct castes or modifications known in America under the name of mulatto, quarteroons, etc., although found in the Philippine Islands, are generally confounded in the three classes of pure Indians, Chinese mestizos and Chinese". In other words, the Mexicans who had arrived in the previous century had so intermingled with the local population that distinctions of origin had been forgotten by the 19th century. The Mexicans who came with Legázpi and aboard succeeding vessels had blended with the local residents so well that their country of origin had been erased from memory.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Filipino-Mexican-Central-and-South+American+Connection%2C+Tales+of+Two+Sisters%3A+Manila+and+Mexico&amp;rft.date=1997-06-21&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Ffilipinokastila.tripod.com%2FFilMex.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-82"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-82">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">(Page 10) <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation thesis cs1" id="CITEREFPérez2015">Pérez, Marilola (2015). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210114232555/https://escholarship.org/content/qt6xj6f1jt/qt6xj6f1jt_noSplash_fd187448d1120e8904337fe47b42df2a.pdf" rel="nofollow"><i>Cavite Chabacano Philippine Creole Spanish: Description and Typology</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> (PhD). University of California, Berkeley. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://escholarship.org/uc/item/6xj6f1jt" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on January 14, 2021. <q>The galleon activities also attracted a great number of Mexican men that arrived from the Mexican Pacific coast as ships' crewmembers (Grant 2009: 230). Mexicans were administrators, priests and soldiers (guachinangos or hombres de pueblo) (Bernal 1964: 188) many though, integrated into the peasant society, even becoming tulisanes 'bandits' who in the late 18th century "infested" Cavite and led peasant revolts (Medina 2002: 66). Meanwhile, in the Spanish garrisons, Spanish was used among administrators and priests. Nonetheless, there is not enough historical information on the social role of these men. In fact some of the few references point to a quick integration into the local society: "<i>los hombres del pueblo, los soldados y marinos, anónimos, olvidados, absorbidos en su totalidad por la población Filipina.</i>" (Bernal 1964: 188). In addition to the Manila-Acapulco galleon, a complex commercial maritime system circulated European and Asian commodities including slaves. During the 17th century, Portuguese vessels traded with the ports of Manila and Cavite, even after the prohibition of 1644 (Seijas 2008: 21). Crucially, the commercial activities included the smuggling and trade of slaves: "from the Moluccas, and Malacca, and India … with the monsoon winds" carrying "clove spice, cinnamon, and pepper and black slaves, and Kafir [slaves]" (Antonio de Morga cf Seijas 2008: 21). Though there is no data on the numbers of slaves in Cavite, the numbers in Manila suggest a significant fraction of the population had been brought in as slaves by the Portuguese vessels. By 1621, slaves in Manila numbered 1,970 out of a population of 6,110. This influx of slaves continued until late in the 17th century; according to contemporary cargo records in 1690, 200 slaves departed from Malacca to Manila (Seijas 2008: 21). Different ethnicities were favored for different labor; Africans were brought to work on the agricultural production, and skilled slaves from India served as caulkers and carpenters.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Adissertation&amp;rft.title=Cavite+Chabacano+Philippine+Creole+Spanish%3A+Description+and+Typology&amp;rft.inst=University+of+California%2C+Berkeley&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.aulast=P%C3%A9rez&amp;rft.aufirst=Marilola&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fescholarship.org%2Fuc%2Fitem%2F6xj6f1jt&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-83"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-83">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFTatiana_Seijas2014">Tatiana Seijas (2014). <a class="external text" href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/Asian_Slaves_in_Colonial_Mexico/YCWjAwAAQBAJ?hl=en&amp;gbpv=1&amp;pg=PA32" rel="nofollow">"The Diversity and Reach of the Manila Slave Market"</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/Asian_Slaves_in_Colonial_Mexico/YCWjAwAAQBAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Asian Slaves in Colonial Mexico</i></a>. p. 36. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-107-06312-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-107-06312-9"><bdi>978-1-107-06312-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Diversity+and+Reach+of+the+Manila+Slave+Market&amp;rft.btitle=Asian+Slaves+in+Colonial+Mexico&amp;rft.pages=36&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-107-06312-9&amp;rft.au=Tatiana+Seijas&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2Fbooks%2Fedition%2FAsian_Slaves_in_Colonial_Mexico%2FYCWjAwAAQBAJ%3Fhl%3Den%26gbpv%3D1%26pg%3DPA32&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-84"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-84">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDolan1991">Dolan 1991</a>, <a class="external text" href="http://countrystudies.us/philippines/4.htm" rel="nofollow">The Early Spanish Period</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-85">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFNewson2009">Newson, Linda A. <li id="cite_note-86"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-86">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCrossley2013">Crossley, John Newsome (July 28, 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=jQmiAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA168" rel="nofollow"><i>Hernando de los Ríos Coronel and the Spanish Philippines in the Golden Age</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-87"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-87">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFNewson2009">Newson, Linda A. (April 16, 2009). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=A40BEAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA3" rel="nofollow"><i>Conquest and Pestilence in the Early Spanish Philippines</i></a>. University of Hawaii Press. p. 8. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8248-6197-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8248-6197-1"><bdi>978-0-8248-6197-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Conquest+and+Pestilence+in+the+Early+Spanish+Philippines&amp;rft.pages=8&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Hawaii+Press&amp;rft.date=2009-04-16&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8248-6197-1&amp;rft.aulast=Newson&amp;rft.aufirst=Linda+A.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DA40BEAAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA3&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-88"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-88">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCole1985">Cole, Jeffrey A. (1985). <i>The Potosí mita, 1573–1700: compulsory Indian labor in the Andes</i>. Stanford, Calif.: Stanford University Press. p. 20. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8047-1256-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8047-1256-9"><bdi>978-0-8047-1256-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Potos%C3%AD+mita%2C+1573%E2%80%931700%3A+compulsory+Indian+labor+in+the+Andes&amp;rft.place=Stanford%2C+Calif.&amp;rft.pages=20&amp;rft.pub=Stanford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1985&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8047-1256-9&amp;rft.aulast=Cole&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeffrey+A.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-89">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHawkley2014">Hawkley, Ethan (2014). <a class="external text" href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/276488434" rel="nofollow">"Reviving the Reconquista in Southeast Asia: Moros and the Making of the Philippines, 1565–1662"</a>. <i>Journal of World History</i>. University of Hawai'i Press. <b>25</b> (2–3): 288. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1353%2Fjwh.2014.0014" rel="nofollow">10.1353/jwh.2014.0014</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:143692647" rel="nofollow">143692647</a>. <q>The early modern revival of the Reconquista in the Philippines had a profound effect on the islands, one that is still being felt today. As described above, the Spanish Reconquista served to unify Christians against a common Moro enemy, helping to bring together Castilian, Catalan, Galician, and Basque peoples into a single political unit: Spain. In precolonial times, the Philippine islands were a divided and unspecified part of the Malay archipelago, one inhabited by dozens of ethnolinguistic groups, residing in countless independent villages, strewn across thousands of islands. By the end of the seventeenth century, however, a dramatic change had happened in the archipelago. A multiethnic community had come together to form the colonial beginnings of a someday nation: the Philippines. The powerful influence of Christian-Moro antagonisms on the formation of the early Philippines remains evident more than four hundred years later, as the Philippine national government continues to grapple with Moro separatists groups, even in 2013.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+World+History&amp;rft.atitle=Reviving+the+Reconquista+in+Southeast+Asia%3A+Moros+and+the+Making+of+the+Philippines%2C+1565%E2%80%931662&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2%E2%80%933&amp;rft.pages=288&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1353%2Fjwh.2014.0014&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A143692647%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.aulast=Hawkley&amp;rft.aufirst=Ethan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.researchgate.net%2Fpublication%2F276488434&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFUnited_States_War_Department1903">United States War Department (1903). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=g8FMAAAAYAAJ&amp;pg=PA379" rel="nofollow"><i>Annual Report of the Secretary of War</i></a>. U.S. Government Printing Office. pp. 379–398<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">January 29,</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Annual+Report+of+the+Secretary+of+War&amp;rft.pages=379-398&amp;rft.pub=U.S.+Government+Printing+Office&amp;rft.date=1903&amp;rft.au=United+States+War+Department&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dg8FMAAAAYAAJ%26pg%3DPA379&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-96"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-96">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSteinberg2018">Steinberg, David Joel (2018). "Chapter – 3 A SINGULAR AND A PLURAL FOLK". <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6NFMDwAAQBAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>THE PHILIPPINES A Singular and a Plural Place</i></a>. Routledge. p. 47. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.4324%2F9780429494383" rel="nofollow">10.4324/9780429494383</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8133-3755-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8133-3755-5"><bdi>978-0-8133-3755-5</bdi></a>. <q>The cultural identity of the mestizos was challenged as they became increasingly aware that they were true members of neither the indio nor the Chinese community. Increasingly powerful but adrift, they linked with the Spanish mestizos, who were also being challenged because after the Latin American revolutions broke the Spanish Empire, many of the settlers from the New World, Caucasian Creoles born in Mexico or Peru, became suspect in the eyes of the Iberian Spanish. The Spanish Empire had lost its universality.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Chapter+%E2%80%93+3+A+SINGULAR+AND+A+PLURAL+FOLK&amp;rft.btitle=THE+PHILIPPINES+A+Singular+and+a+Plural+Place&amp;rft.pages=47&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.4324%2F9780429494383&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8133-3755-5&amp;rft.aulast=Steinberg&amp;rft.aufirst=David+Joel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D6NFMDwAAQBAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-104"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-104">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFStarr1988">Starr, J. <li id="cite_note-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-105">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDraper1899">Draper, Andrew Sloan (1899). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=MD8OAAAAIAAJ&amp;pg=PA170" rel="nofollow"><i>The Rescue of Cuba: An Episode in the Growth of Free Government</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-154"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-154">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200806030349/https://www.refworld.org/pdfid/4d5a310e2.pdf" rel="nofollow">"The Communist Insurgency in the Philippines: Tactics and Talks"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Refworld</i>. Asia Report N°202. February 14, 2011. pp. 5–7. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://www.refworld.org/pdfid/4d5a310e2.pdf" rel="nofollow">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on August 6, 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-203"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-203">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFCollege_of_Forestry_and_Natural_Resources,_University_of_the_Philippines_Los_Baños">College of Forestry and Natural Resources, University of the Philippines Los Baños. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200730173552/https://riverbasin.denr.gov.ph/masterplans/cagayanexecutivesummary.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Climate-Responsive Integrated Master Plan for Cagayan River Basin; Volume I – Executive Summary"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>River Basin Control Office</i>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 30,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=River+Basin+Control+Office&amp;rft.atitle=Climate-Responsive+Integrated+Master+Plan+for+Cagayan+River+Basin%3B+Volume+I+%E2%80%93+Executive+Summary&amp;rft.pages=5&amp;rft.au=College+of+Forestry+and+Natural+Resources%2C+University+of+the+Philippines+Los+Ba%C3%B1os&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Friverbasin.denr.gov.ph%2Fmasterplans%2Fcagayanexecutivesummary.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Jacinto_et_al_(A)-204"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Jacinto_et_al_(A)_204-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Jacinto, G.S., Azanza, R.V., Velasquez, I.B. and Siringan, F.P.(2006). </li>
<li id="cite_note-219"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-219">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFSantos1974">Santos, Gabriel Jr. (1974). <li id="cite_note-230"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-230">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFAgoo2007">Agoo, Esperanza Maribel G. (June 2007). <a class="external text" href="http://asbp.org.ph/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/907-3032-2-PB.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Status of Orchid Taxonomy Research in the Philippines"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Philippine Journal of Systematic Biology</i>. <b>1</b><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 23,</span> 2020</span>. <q>There are over 137 genera and about 998 species of orchids so far recorded for the archipelago. This represents about 10% of the total flora of the Philippines. The Philippines ranks second to New Guinea in occurrence of endemic species in the Malesian region.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Philippine+Journal+of+Systematic+Biology&amp;rft.atitle=Status+of+Orchid+Taxonomy+Research+in+the+Philippines&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.date=2007-06&amp;rft.aulast=Agoo&amp;rft.aufirst=Esperanza+Maribel+G.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fasbp.org.ph%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2F2016%2F09%2F907-3032-2-PB.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Carpenter-234"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Carpenter_234-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFCarpenter,_Kent_E.Victor_G._Springer2005">Carpenter, Kent E. &amp; Victor G. Springer (April 2005). "The center of the center of marine shore fish biodiversity: the Philippine Islands". <i>Environmental Biology of Fishes</i>. <b>74</b> (2): 467–480. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1007%2Fs10641-004-3154-4" rel="nofollow">10.1007/s10641-004-3154-4</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:8280012" rel="nofollow">8280012</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Environmental+Biology+of+Fishes&amp;rft.atitle=The+center+of+the+center+of+marine+shore+fish+biodiversity%3A+the+Philippine+Islands&amp;rft.volume=74&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=467-480&amp;rft.date=2005-04&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1007%2Fs10641-004-3154-4&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A8280012%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.au=Carpenter%2C+Kent+E.&amp;rft.au=Victor+G.+Springer&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-PNAGovPH-PHSeeks-244"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-PNAGovPH-PHSeeks_244-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFTeves2018">Teves, Catherine (December 14, 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20181214235557/http://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1056744" rel="nofollow">"PH seeks more climate action for Coral Triangle"</a>. <i>Philippine News Agency</i>. <li id="cite_note-245"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-245">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBos,_A.R.Smits,_H.M.2013">Bos, A.R. &amp; Smits, H.M. <li id="cite_note-246"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-246">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBos,_Arthur_R.Gumanao,_Girley_S.2013">Bos, Arthur R. &amp; Gumanao, Girley S. <li id="cite_note-247"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-247">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBos,_A.R.Gumanao,_G.S.Salac,_F.N.2008">Bos, A.R.; Gumanao, G.S.; Salac, F.N. (2008). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150703190342/http://www.researchgate.net/publication/225650880_A_newly_discovered_predator_of_the_crown-of-thorns_starfish" rel="nofollow">"A newly discovered predator of the crown-of-thorns starfish"</a>. <i>Coral Reefs</i>. <b>27</b> (3): 581. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2008CorRe..27..581B" rel="nofollow">2008CorRe..27..581B</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1007%2Fs00338-008-0364-9" rel="nofollow">10.1007/s00338-008-0364-9</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:34920961" rel="nofollow">34920961</a>. <li id="cite_note-248"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-248">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFOcañaJ.C._den_HartogA._BritoA.R._Bos2010">Ocaña; J.C. den Hartog; A. <li id="cite_note-gem-253"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-gem_253-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100820011316/http://www.ncca.gov.ph/about-culture-and-arts/culture-profile/phil-fast-facts/culture-profile-pearl.php" rel="nofollow">"Philippine Fast Facts, National Gem: Philippine Pearl"</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Commission_for_Culture_and_the_Arts_(Philippines)" title="National Commission for Culture and the Arts (Philippines)">National Commission for Culture and the Arts</a>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.ncca.gov.ph/about-culture-and-arts/culture-profile/phil-fast-facts/culture-profile-pearl.php" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on August 20, 2010<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 4,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Philippine+Fast+Facts%2C+National+Gem%3A+Philippine+Pearl&amp;rft.pub=National+Commission+for+Culture+and+the+Arts&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncca.gov.ph%2Fabout-culture-and-arts%2Fculture-profile%2Fphil-fast-facts%2Fculture-profile-pearl.php&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-PAGASA-Climate-254"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-PAGASA-Climate_254-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-PAGASA-Climate_254-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180418140425/http://bagong.pagasa.dost.gov.ph/information/climate-philippines" rel="nofollow">"Climate of the Philippines"</a>. <i>Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration</i>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://bagong.pagasa.dost.gov.ph/information/climate-philippines" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on April 18, 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 24,</span> 2020</span>. <q>Based on the average of all weather stations in the Philippines, excluding Baguio, the mean annual temperature is 26.6o C. The coolest months fall in January with a mean temperature of 25.5oC while the warmest month occurs in May with a mean temperature of 28.3oC. Latitude is an insignificant factor in the variation of temperature while altitude shows greater contrast in temperature. Thus, the mean annual temperature of Baguio with an elevation of 1,500 meters is 18.3oC.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Philippine+Atmospheric%2C+Geophysical+and+Astronomical+Services+Administration&amp;rft.atitle=Climate+of+the+Philippines&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbagong.pagasa.dost.gov.ph%2Finformation%2Fclimate-philippines&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-cp-255"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-cp_255-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cp_255-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Library_of_Congress" title="Library of Congress">Library of Congress</a> – <a href="/wiki/Federal_Research_Division" title="Federal Research Division">Federal Research Division</a>. <li id="cite_note-Rose-Ackerman-262"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Rose-Ackerman_262-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Rose-Ackerman_262-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Rose-Ackerman_262-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFRose-AckermanDesiertoVolosin2011">Rose-Ackerman, Susan; Desierto, Diane A.; Volosin, Natalia (2011). <a class="external text" href="https://digitalcommons.law.yale.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=5170&amp;context=fss_papers" rel="nofollow">"Hyper-Presidentialism: Separation of Powers without Checks and Balances in Argentina and Philippines"</a>. <i>Berkeley Journal of International Law</i>. <b>29</b>: 246–333.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Berkeley+Journal+of+International+Law&amp;rft.atitle=Hyper-Presidentialism%3A+Separation+of+Powers+without+Checks+and+Balances+in+Argentina+and+Philippines&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.pages=246-333&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.aulast=Rose-Ackerman&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.au=Desierto%2C+Diane+A.&amp;rft.au=Volosin%2C+Natalia&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fdigitalcommons.law.yale.edu%2Fcgi%2Fviewcontent.cgi%3Farticle%3D5170%26context%3Dfss_papers&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-295"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-295">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSanders2015">Sanders, Vivienne (2015). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=YOQqCgAAQBAJ&amp;q=%22philippines%22+united+states+korean+war+7,500&amp;pg=PT44" rel="nofollow"><i>Access to History: The Cold War in Asia 1945–93 for OCR Second Edition</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-332"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-332">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Florante S. Solmerin, December 7, 2013, Manila Standard, <a class="external text" href="http://manilastandardtoday.com/2013/12/07/abu-sayyaf-keeping-17-foreigners-hostage/" rel="nofollow">Abu Sayyaf keeping 17 foreigners hostage</a>, Retrieved July 6, 2020. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141006085118/http://manilastandardtoday.com/2013/12/07/abu-sayyaf-keeping-17-foreigners-hostage/" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> October 6, 2014, at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>, Retrieved September 3, 2014, "...17 foreigners, mostly birdwatchers, were being held hostage by the Abu Sayyaf Group..."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-333"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-333">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Roel Pareño, The Philippine Star, March 24, 2013, <a class="external text" href="http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2013/03/24/923345/sayyaf-releases-aussie-hostage" rel="nofollow">Sayyaf releases Aussie hostage</a>, Retrieved July 6, 2020, "...Australian Warren Rodwell emerged early yesterday withered after being held for 15 months by Abu Sayyaf bandits in southern Mindanao..."</span>

<li id="cite_note-334"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-334">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sun Star, April 25, 2014, <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140427122931/http://www.sunstar.com.ph/breaking-news/2014/04/25/abducted-tourist-hotel-staff-now-sulu-339790" rel="nofollow">Abducted tourist, hotel staff now in Sulu</a>, Retrieved September 3, 2014, "...Abu Sayyaf bandits have brought a Chinese tourist and a Filipino hotel receptionist to their jungle stronghold in southern Philippines after kidnapping the women from a dive resort in eastern Malaysia ..."</span>

<li id="cite_note-367"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-367">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Bawagan, A. B. (2009). Customary Justice System among the Iraya Mangyans of Mindoro. AGHAMTAO: Journal of Ugnayang Pang-Aghamtao, Inc. (UGAT), Volume 17, 16.</span>

<li id="cite_note-376"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-376">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFSoaresTrejautRitoCavadas2016">Soares, PA; Trejaut, JA; Rito, T; Cavadas, B; Hill, C; Eng, KK; Mormina, M; Brandão, A; Fraser, RM; Wang, TY; Loo, JH; Snell, C; Ko, TM; Amorim, A; Pala, M; Macaulay, V; Bulbeck, D; Wilson, JF; Gusmão, L; Pereira, L; Oppenheimer, S; Lin, M; Richards, MB (2016). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4757630" rel="nofollow">"Resolving the ancestry of Austronesian-speaking populations"</a>. <i>Hum Genet</i>. <b>135</b> (3): 309–26. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1007%2Fs00439-015-1620-z" rel="nofollow">10.1007/s00439-015-1620-z</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4757630" rel="nofollow">4757630</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Hum+Genet&amp;rft.atitle=Resolving+the+ancestry+of+Austronesian-speaking+populations&amp;rft.volume=135&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=309-26&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC4757630%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F26781090&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1007%2Fs00439-015-1620-z&amp;rft.aulast=Soares&amp;rft.aufirst=PA&amp;rft.au=Trejaut%2C+JA&amp;rft.au=Rito%2C+T&amp;rft.au=Cavadas%2C+B&amp;rft.au=Hill%2C+C&amp;rft.au=Eng%2C+KK&amp;rft.au=Mormina%2C+M&amp;rft.au=Brand%C3%A3o%2C+A&amp;rft.au=Fraser%2C+RM&amp;rft.au=Wang%2C+TY&amp;rft.au=Loo%2C+JH&amp;rft.au=Snell%2C+C&amp;rft.au=Ko%2C+TM&amp;rft.au=Amorim%2C+A&amp;rft.au=Pala%2C+M&amp;rft.au=Macaulay%2C+V&amp;rft.au=Bulbeck%2C+D&amp;rft.au=Wilson%2C+JF&amp;rft.au=Gusm%C3%A3o%2C+L&amp;rft.au=Pereira%2C+L&amp;rft.au=Oppenheimer%2C+S&amp;rft.au=Lin%2C+M&amp;rft.au=Richards%2C+MB&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC4757630&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines"></span> The final component (dark blue in Fig. 3b) has a high frequency in South China (Fig. 2b) and is also seen in Taiwan at ~25–30 %, <b>in the Philippines at ~20–30 %</b> (except in one location which is almost zero) and across Indonesia/Malaysia at 1–10 %, declining overall from Taiwan within Austronesian-speaking populations.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-380"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-380">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFWong1999">Wong, Kwok-Chu (1999). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QZQ0aAAAZ4cC&amp;pg=PA15" rel="nofollow"><i>The Chinese in the Philippine Economy, 1898–1941</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-383"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-383">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFCooper2013">Cooper, Matthew (November 15, 2013). <a class="external text" href="http://www.nationaljournal.com/magazine/why-the-philippines-is-america-s-forgotten-colony-20131115" rel="nofollow">"Why the Philippines Is America's Forgotten Colony"</a>. <i>National Journal</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">January 28,</span> 2015</span>. <q>c. <li id="cite_note-384"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-384">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation pressrelease cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://amerasianresearch.org/releases/amerasianresearch-2012-09.pdf" rel="nofollow">"200,000–250,000 or More Military Filipino Amerasians Alive Today in Republic of the Philippines according to USA-RP Joint Research Paper Finding"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Amerasian Research Network, Ltd.</i> (Press release). (October 2012). <a class="external text" href="http://amerasianresearch.org/pdf/ICOPHIL-9FINALFilipinoDiaspora-Kutschera-Caputi.pdf" rel="nofollow">"The Case for Categorization of Military Filipino Amerasians as Diaspora"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. 9th International Conference On the Philippines, Michigan State University, E.
